CREATE_RELATION.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.CREATE_RELATION(tname      in    varchar2,
                         phrase     in    varchar2,
                         rel        in    varchar2,
                         relphrase  in    varchar2);
CREATE_RELATION.descriptionText: Creates a relation between two phrases in the thesaurus. The synonym ring is limited in length to about 4000 synonyms, depending on word length.

CREATE_THESAURUS.name: ctx_thes.create_thesaurus
CREATE_THESAURUS.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.CREATE_THESAURUS(name           IN VARCHAR2,
                          casesens       IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
CREATE_THESAURUS.descriptionText: The CREATE_THESAURUS procedure creates an empty thesaurus with the specified name in the thesaurus tables.

CREATE_TRANSLATION.name: ctx_thes.create_translation
CREATE_TRANSLATION.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.CREATE_TRANSLATION(tname       in    varchar2,
                            phrase      in    varchar2,
                            language    in    varchar2,
                            translation in    varchar2);
CREATE_TRANSLATION.descriptionText: Use this procedure to create a new translation for a phrase in a specified language.

DROP_PHRASE.name: ctx_thes.drop_phrase
DROP_PHRASE.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.DROP_PHRASE(tname      in varchar2, 
                     phrase     in varchar2);
DROP_PHRASE.descriptionText: Removes a phrase from the thesaurus. Only thesaurus owner and CTXSYS can invoke this procedure on a given thesaurus.

DROP_RELATION.name: ctx_thes.drop_relation
DROP_RELATION.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.DROP_RELATION(tname     in    varchar2,
                        phrase    in    varchar2,
                        rel       in    varchar2,
                        relphrase in    varchar2 default null);
DROP_RELATION.descriptionText: Removes a relation between two phrases from the thesaurus.

DROP_THESAURUS.name: ctx_thes.drop_thesaurus
DROP_THESAURUS.descriptionText: The DROP_THESAURUS procedure deletes the specified thesaurus and all of its entries from the thesaurus tables.

DROP_TRANSLATION.name: ctx_thes.drop_translation
DROP_TRANSLATION.body:
tname => $1
	, phrase => $2
	, language => null
	, translation => null
DROP_TRANSLATION.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.DROP_TRANSLATION (tname       in    varchar2,
                           phrase      in    varchar2,
                           language    in    varchar2 default null,
                           translation in    varchar2 default null);
DROP_TRANSLATION.descriptionText: Use this procedure to remove one or more translations for a phrase.

EXPORT_THESAURUS.name: ctx_thes.export_thesaurus
EXPORT_THESAURUS.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.EXPORT_THESAURUS(name in varchar2, 
                          thesdump in out nocopy CLOB);
EXPORT_THESAURUS.descriptionText: Use this procedure to export a thesaurus as a clob from the Oracle Text thesaurus tables. The format of the exported thesaurus is same as that of the format of the thesaurus file that is used by the ctxload utility to import thesaurus into the Oracle Text thesaurus tables.

HAS_RELATION.name: ctx_thes.has_relation
HAS_RELATION.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.HAS_RELATION(phrase in varchar2, 
                      rel in varchar2, 
                      tname in varchar2 default 'DEFAULT')
  returns boolean;
HAS_RELATION.descriptionText: HAS_RELATION tests that a thesaurus relation exists without actually performing the expansion. The function returns TRUE if the phrase has any of the relations in the specified list.

IMPORT_THESAURUS.name: ctx_thes.import_thesaurus
IMPORT_THESAURUS.descriptionText: Use this procedure to import a thesaurus into the Oracle Text thesaurus tables. You should call ctx_output.start_log before calling import_thesaurus to log the operations done by import_thesaurus.

NT.name: ctx_thes.nt
NT.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.NT(restab IN OUT NOCOPY EXP_TAB,
             phrase IN VARCHAR2, 
             lvl    IN NUMBER DEFAULT 1,
             tname  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'DEFAULT');
NT.descriptionText: This function returns all narrower terms of a phrase as recorded in the specified thesaurus.

NTG.name: ctx_thes.ntg
NTG.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.NTG(restab IN OUT NOCOPY EXP_TAB,
             phrase IN VARCHAR2, 
             lvl    IN NUMBER DEFAULT 1,
             tname  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'DEFAULT');
NTG.descriptionText: This function returns all narrower terms generic of a phrase as recorded in the specified thesaurus.

NTI.name: ctx_thes.nti
NTI.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.NTI(restab IN OUT NOCOPY EXP_TAB,
             phrase IN VARCHAR2, 
             lvl    IN NUMBER DEFAULT 1,
             tname  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'DEFAULT');
NTI.descriptionText: This function returns all narrower terms instance of a phrase as recorded in the specified thesaurus.

NTP.name: ctx_thes.ntp
NTP.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.NTP(restab IN OUT NOCOPY EXP_TAB,
             phrase IN VARCHAR2, 
             lvl    IN NUMBER DEFAULT 1,
             tname  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'DEFAULT');
NTP.descriptionText: This function returns all narrower terms partitive of a phrase as recorded in the specified thesaurus.

OUTPUT_STYLE.name: ctx_thes.output_style
OUTPUT_STYLE.body:
showlevel => FALSE
	, showqualify => FALSE
	, showpt => FALSE
	, showid => FALSE
OUTPUT_STYLE.descriptionText: Sets the output style for the return string of the CTX_THES expansion functions. This procedure has no effect on the table results to the CTX_THES expansion functions.

PT.name: ctx_thes.pt
PT.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.PT(restab IN OUT NOCOPY EXP_TAB,
            phrase IN VARCHAR2,
            tname  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'DEFAULT')
RETURN varchar2;
PT.descriptionText: This function returns the preferred term of a phrase as recorded in the specified thesaurus.

RT.name: ctx_thes.rt
RT.descriptionText: This function returns the related terms of a term in the specified thesaurus.

SN.name: ctx_thes.sn
SN.descriptionText: This function returns the scope note of the given phrase.

SYN.name: ctx_thes.syn
SYN.descriptionText: This function returns all synonyms of a phrase as recorded in the specified thesaurus.

THES_TT.name: ctx_thes.thes_tt
THES_TT.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.THES_TT(restab IN OUT NOCOPY EXP_TAB,
                 tname  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'DEFAULT');
THES_TT.descriptionText: This procedure finds and returns all top terms of a thesaurus. A top term is defined as any term which has a narrower term but has no broader terms.

TR.name: ctx_thes.tr
TR.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.TR(restab IN OUT NOCOPY EXP_TAB,
            phrase IN VARCHAR2, 
            lang   IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
            tname  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'DEFAULT')
TR.descriptionText: For a given mono-lingual thesaurus, this function returns the foreign language equivalent of a phrase as recorded in the thesaurus.

TRSYN.name: ctx_thes.trsyn
TRSYN.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.TRSYN(restab IN OUT NOCOPY EXP_TAB,
               phrase IN VARCHAR2, 
               lang   IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
               tname  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'DEFAULT');
TRSYN.descriptionText: For a given mono-lingual thesaurus, this function returns the foreign equivalent of a phrase, synonyms of the phrase, and foreign equivalent of the synonyms as recorded in the specified thesaurus.

TT.name: ctx_thes.tt
TT.descriptionText: This function returns the top term of a phrase as recorded in the specified thesaurus.

UPDATE_TRANSLATION.name: ctx_thes.update_translation
UPDATE_TRANSLATION.bodyFullText:
CTX_THES.UPDATE_TRANSLATION(tname       in     varchar2,
                             phrase      in     varchar2,
                             language    in     varchar2,
                             translation in     varchar2,
                             new_translation in varchar2);
UPDATE_TRANSLATION.descriptionText: Use this procedure to update an existing translation.

ANALYZE_DB.name: dbms_addm.analyze_db
ANALYZE_DB.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADDM.ANALYZE_DB (
   task_name           IN OUT VARCHAR2,
   begin_snapshot      IN     NUMBER,
   end_snapshot        IN     NUMBER,
   db_id               IN     NUMBER := NULL);
ANALYZE_DB.descriptionText: This procedure creates an ADDM task for analyzing in database analysis mode and executes it.

ANALYZE_INST.name: dbms_addm.analyze_inst
ANALYZE_INST.body:
task_name => $1
	, begin_snapshot => $2
	, end_snapshot => $3
	, instance_number => NULL
	, db_id => NULL
ANALYZE_INST.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADDM.ANALYZE_INST (
   task_name           IN OUT VARCHAR2,
   begin_snapshot      IN     NUMBER,
   end_snapshot        IN     NUMBER,
   instance_number     IN     NUMBER := NULL,
   db_id               IN     NUMBER := NULL);
ANALYZE_INST.descriptionText: This procedure creates an ADDM task for analyzing in instance analysis mode and executes it.

ANALYZE_PARTIAL.name: dbms_addm.analyze_partial
ANALYZE_PARTIAL.body:
task_name => $1
	, instance_numbers => $2
	, begin_snapshot => $3
	, end_snapshot => $4
	, db_id => NULL
ANALYZE_PARTIAL.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADDM.ANALYZE_PARTIAL (
   task_name           IN OUT VARCHAR2,
   instance_numbers    IN     VARCHAR2,
   begin_snapshot      IN     NUMBER,
   end_snapshot        IN     NUMBER,
   db_id               IN     NUMBER := NULL);
ANALYZE_PARTIAL.descriptionText: This procedure creates an ADDM task for analyzing a subset of instances in partial analysis mode and executes it.

COMPARE_CAPTURE_REPLAY_REPORT.name: dbms_addm.compare_capture_replay_report
COMPARE_CAPTURE_REPLAY_REPORT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADDM.COMPARE_CAPTURE_REPLAY_REPORT (
   replay_id             IN NUMBER,
   report_type           IN VARCHAR2 := 'HTML')
  RETURN CLOB;
COMPARE_CAPTURE_REPLAY_REPORT.descriptionText: This function produces a Compare Period ADDM report comparing the performance of a capture to a replay. The AWR data must reside in the same database, but it can originate from different databases. The function generates a report in either XML or HTML(Active Report) format.

COMPARE_DATABASES.name: dbms_addm.compare_databases
COMPARE_DATABASES.body:
base_dbid => NULL
	, base_begin_snap_id => $1
	, base_end_snap_id => $2
	, comp_dbid => NULL
	, comp_begin_snap_id => $3
	, comp_end_snap_id => $4
	, report_type => 'HTML'
COMPARE_DATABASES.bodyNoDefault:
base_dbid => $1
	, base_begin_snap_id => $2
	, base_end_snap_id => $3
	, comp_dbid => $4
	, comp_begin_snap_id => $5
	, comp_end_snap_id => $6
	, report_type => $7
COMPARE_DATABASES.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADDM.COMPARE_DATABASES (
   base_dbid             IN NUMBER := NULL,
   base_begin_snap_id    IN NUMBER,
   base_end_snap_id      IN NUMBER,
   comp_dbid             IN NUMBER := NULL,
   comp_begin_snap_id    IN NUMBER,
   comp_end_snap_id      IN NUMBER,
   report_type           IN VARCHAR2 := 'HTML')
  RETURN CLOB;
COMPARE_DATABASES.descriptionText: This function produces a Compare Period ADDM report comparing the performance of a database over two different time periods or the performance of two different databases over two different time periods.The AWR data must reside in the same database, but it can originate from different databases. The function generates a report in either XML or HTML(Active Report) format.

COMPARE_INSTANCES.name: dbms_addm.compare_instances
COMPARE_INSTANCES.body:
base_dbid => NULL
	, base_instance_id => $1
	, base_begin_snap_id => $2
	, base_end_snap_id => $3
	, comp_dbid => NULL
	, comp_instance_id => $4
	, comp_begin_snap_id => $5
	, comp_end_snap_id => $6
	, report_type => 'HTML'
COMPARE_INSTANCES.bodyNoDefault:
base_dbid => $1
	, base_instance_id => $2
	, base_begin_snap_id => $3
	, base_end_snap_id => $4
	, comp_dbid => $5
	, comp_instance_id => $6
	, comp_begin_snap_id => $7
	, comp_end_snap_id => $8
	, report_type => $9
COMPARE_INSTANCES.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADDM.COMPARE_INSTANCES (
   base_dbid             IN NUMBER := NULL,
   base_instance_id      IN NUMBER
   base_begin_snap_id    IN NUMBER,
   base_end_snap_id      IN NUMBER,
   comp_dbid             IN NUMBER := NULL,
   comp_instance_id      IN NUMBER,
   comp_begin_snap_id    IN NUMBER,
   comp_end_snap_id      IN  NUMBER,
   report_type           IN VARCHAR2 := 'HTML')
  RETURN CLOB;
COMPARE_INSTANCES.descriptionText: This function produces a Compare Period ADDM report comparing the performance of a single instance over two different time periods or the performance of two different instances over two different time periods.The AWR data must reside in the same database, but it can originate from different databases. The function generates a report in either XML or HTML(Active Report) format.

DELETE.name: dbms_addm.delete
DELETE.descriptionText: This procedure deletes an already created ADDM task (of any kind). For database analysis mode and partial analysis mode this deletes the local tasks associated with the main task.

DELETE_FINDING_DIRECTIVE.name: dbms_addm.delete_finding_directive
DELETE_FINDING_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure deletes a finding directive.

DELETE_PARAMETER_DIRECTIVE.name: dbms_addm.delete_parameter_directive
DELETE_PARAMETER_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure deletes a parameter directive. This removes a specific system directive for parameters. Subsequent ADDM tasks are not affected by this directive.

DELETE_SEGMENT_DIRECTIVE.name: dbms_addm.delete_segment_directive
DELETE_SEGMENT_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure deletes a segment directive.

DELETE_SQL_DIRECTIVE.name: dbms_addm.delete_sql_directive
DELETE_SQL_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure deletes a SQL directive.

GET_ASH_QUERY.name: dbms_addm.get_ash_query
GET_ASH_QUERY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADDM.GET_ASH_QUERY (
   task_name           IN   VARCHAR2,
   finding_id          IN   NUMBER)
  RETURN VARCHAR2;
GET_ASH_QUERY.descriptionText: The function returns a string containing the SQL text of an ASH query identifying the rows in ASH with impact for the finding. For most types of findings this identifies the exact rows in ASH corresponding to the finding. For some types of findings the query is an approximation and should not be used for exact identification of the findin\'s impact or the findin\'s specific activity.

GET_REPORT.name: dbms_addm.get_report
GET_REPORT.descriptionText: This function retrieves the default text report of an executed ADDM task.

INSERT_FINDING_DIRECTIVE.name: dbms_addm.insert_finding_directive
INSERT_FINDING_DIRECTIVE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADDM.INSERT_FINDING_DIRECTIVE (
   task_name             IN VARCHAR2,
   dir_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   finding_name          IN VARCHAR2,
   min_active_sessions   IN NUMBER := 0,
   min_perc_impact       IN NUMBER := 0);
INSERT_FINDING_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a directive to limit reporting of a specific finding type. The directive can be created for a specific task (only when the task is in INITIAL status), or for all subsequently created ADDM tasks (such as a system directive).

INSERT_PARAMETER_DIRECTIVE.name: dbms_addm.insert_parameter_directive
INSERT_PARAMETER_DIRECTIVE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADDM.INSERT_PARAMETER_DIRECTIVE (
   task_name             IN VARCHAR2,
   dir_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   parameter_name        IN VARCHAR2);
INSERT_PARAMETER_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a directive to prevent ADDM from creating actions to alter the value of a specific system parameter. The directive can be created for a specific task (only when the task is in INITIAL status), or for all subsequently created ADDM tasks (such as a system directive).

INSERT_SEGMENT_DIRECTIVE.name: dbms_addm.insert_segment_directive
INSERT_SEGMENT_DIRECTIVE.body:
task_name => $1
	, dir_name => $2
	, owner_name => $3
	, object_name => NULL
	, sub_object_name => NULL
INSERT_SEGMENT_DIRECTIVE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADDM.INSERT_SEGMENT_DIRECTIVE (
   task_name             IN VARCHAR2,
   dir_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   owner_name            IN VARCHAR2,
   object_name           IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   sub_object_name       IN VARCHAR2 := NULL);
   
DBMS_ADDM.INSERT_SEGMENT_DIRECTIVE (
   task_name             IN VARCHAR2,
   dir_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   object_number         IN NUMBER);
INSERT_SEGMENT_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a directive to prevent ADDM from creating actions to "run Segment Advisor" for specific segments. The directive can be created for a specific task (only when the task is in INITIAL status), or for all subsequently created ADDM tasks (such as a system directive).

INSERT_SQL_DIRECTIVE.name: dbms_addm.insert_sql_directive
INSERT_SQL_DIRECTIVE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADDM.INSERT_SQL_DIRECTIVE (
   task_name             IN VARCHAR2,
   dir_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   sql_id                IN VARCHAR2,
   min_active_sessions   IN NUMBER := 0,
   min_response_time     IN NUMBER := 0);
INSERT_SQL_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a directive to limit reporting of actions on specific SQL. The directive can be created for a specific task (only when the task is in INITIAL status), or for all subsequently created ADDM tasks (such as a system directive).

REAL_TIME_ADDM_REPORT.name: dbms_addm.real_time_addm_report
REAL_TIME_ADDM_REPORT.descriptionText: This function produces a real-time ADDM report for ADDM-related activity for the last five minutes. In an Oracle Real Application Clusters (Oracle RAC) environment, the function assumes that executing SQL over GV$ is possible.

ALTER_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE.name: dbms_advanced_rewrite.alter_rewrite_equivalence
ALTER_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE.descriptionText: This procedure changes the mode of the rewrite equivalence declaration to the mode you specify.

DECLARE_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE.name: dbms_advanced_rewrite.declare_rewrite_equivalence
DECLARE_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE.body:
name => $1
	, source_stmt => $2
	, destination_stmt => $3
	, validate => TRUE
	, rewrite_mode => 'TEXT_MATCH'
DECLARE_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADVANCED_REWRITE.DECLARE_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE (
   name                 VARCHAR2,
   source_stmt          VARCHAR2,
   destination_stmt     VARCHAR2,
   validate             BOOLEAN    := TRUE,
   rewrite_mode         VARCHAR2   := 'TEXT_MATCH');

DBMS_ADVANCED_REWRITE.DECLARE_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE (
   name                 VARCHAR2,
   source_stmt          CLOB,
   destination_stmt     CLOB,
   validate             BOOLEAN   := TRUE,
   rewrite_mode         VARCHAR2  := 'TEXT_MATCH');
DECLARE_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a declaration indicating that source_stmt is functionally equivalent to destination_stmt for as long as the equivalence declaration remains enabled, and that destination_stmt is more favorable in terms of performance. The scope of the declaration is system wide. The query rewrite engine uses such declarations to perform rewrite transformations in QUERY_REWRITE_INTEGRITY = trusted and stale_tolerated modes.

DROP_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE.name: dbms_advanced_rewrite.drop_rewrite_equivalence
DROP_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE.descriptionText: This procedure drops the specified rewrite equivalence declaration.

VALIDATE_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE.name: dbms_advanced_rewrite.validate_rewrite_equivalence
VALIDATE_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE.descriptionText: This procedure validates the specified rewrite equivalence declaration using the same validation method as described with the VALIDATE parameter in "VALIDATE_REWRITE_EQUIVALENCE Procedure".

ADD_SQLWKLD_REF.name: dbms_advisor.add_sqlwkld_ref
ADD_SQLWKLD_REF.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADVISOR.ADD_SQLWKLD_REF (

ADD_STS_REF.name: dbms_advisor.add_sts_ref
ADD_STS_REF.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADVISOR.ADD_STS_REF(
  task_name       IN VARCHAR2 NOT NULL,
  sts_owner       IN VARCHAR2,
  workload_name   IN VARCHAR2 NOT NULL);
ADD_STS_REF.descriptionText: This procedure establishes a link between the current SQL Access Advisor task and a SQL tuning set. The link enables an advisor task to access data for the purpose of doing an analysis. The link also provides a stable view of the data. Once a connection between a SQL Access Advisor task and a SQL tuning set is made, the STS is protected from removal or modification.

CANCEL_TASK.name: dbms_advisor.cancel_task
CANCEL_TASK.descriptionText: This procedure causes a currently executing operation to terminate. This call does a soft interrupt. It will not break into a low-level database access call like a hard interrupt such as Ctrl-C. The SQL Access Advisor periodically checks for soft interrupts and acts appropriately. As a result, this operation may take a few seconds to respond to a call.

COPY_SQLWKLD_TO_STS.name: dbms_advisor.copy_sqlwkld_to_sts
COPY_SQLWKLD_TO_STS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADVISOR.COPY_SQLWKLD_TO_STS (
   workload_name         IN VARCHAR2,
   sts_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   import_mode           IN VARCHAR2 := 'NEW');
COPY_SQLWKLD_TO_STS.descriptionText: This procedure copies the contents of a SQL workload object to a SQL tuning set.

CREATE_FILE.name: dbms_advisor.create_file
CREATE_FILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ADVISOR.CREATE_FILE (
   buffer       IN  CLOB,
   location     IN  VARCHAR2,
   filename     IN  VARCHAR2);
CREATE_FILE.descriptionText: This procedure creates an external file from a PL/SQL CLOB variable, which is used for creating scripts and reports. CREATE_FILE accepts a CLOB input parameter and writes the character string contents to the specified file.

DBMS_ADVISOR.CREATE_OBJECT (

DBMS_ADVISOR.CREATE_TASK (
   parent_task_name      IN VARCHAR2,
   rec_id                IN NUMBER,
   task_id               OUT NUMBER,

REGISTER.name: dbms_alert.register
REGISTER.descriptionText: This procedure lets a session register interest in an alert.

REMOVE.name: dbms_alert.remove
REMOVE.descriptionText: This procedure enables a session that is no longer interested in an alert to remove that alert from its registration list. Removing an alert reduces the amount of work done by signalers of the alert.

REMOVEALL.name: dbms_alert.removeall
REMOVEALL.descriptionText: This procedure removes all alerts for this session from the registration list. You should do this when the session is no longer interested in any alerts.

SET_DEFAULTS.name: dbms_alert.set_defaults
SET_DEFAULTS.descriptionText: In case a polling loop is required, use the SET_DEFAULTS procedure to set the polling interval.

SIGNAL.name: dbms_alert.signal
SIGNAL.descriptionText: This procedure signals an alert. The effect of the SIGNAL call only occurs when the transaction in which it is made commits. If the transaction rolls back, SIGNAL has no effect.

WAITANY.name: dbms_alert.waitany
WAITANY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ALERT.WAITANY (
   name      OUT  VARCHAR2,
   message   OUT  VARCHAR2,
   status    OUT  INTEGER,
   timeout   IN   NUMBER DEFAULT MAXWAIT);
WAITANY.descriptionText: Call this procedure to wait for an alert to occur for any of the alerts for which the current session is registered.

WAITONE.name: dbms_alert.waitone
WAITONE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ALERT.WAITONE (
   name      IN   VARCHAR2,
   message   OUT  VARCHAR2,
   status    OUT  INTEGER,
   timeout   IN   NUMBER DEFAULT MAXWAIT);
WAITONE.descriptionText: This procedure waits for a specific alert to occur. An implicit COMMIT is issued before this procedure is executed. A session that is the first to signal an alert can also wait for the alert in a subsequent transaction. In this case, remember to commit after the signal and before the wait; otherwise, DBMS_LOCK.REQUEST (which is called by DBMS_ALERT) returns status 4.

   compare             IN BOOLEAN  DEFAULT TRUE,
   apply_database_link IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);

DBMS_APPLY_ADM.COMPARE_OLD_VALUES(
   object_name         IN VARCHAR2,
   column_table        IN DBMS_UTILITY.LNAME_ARRAY,
   operation           IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'UPDATE',
   compare             IN BOOLEAN  DEFAULT TRUE,
   apply_database_link IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
COMPARE_OLD_VALUES.descriptionText: This procedure specifies whether to compare the old values of one or more columns in a row logical change record (row LCR) with the current values of the corresponding columns at the destination site during apply. This procedure is relevant only for UPDATE and DELETE operations because only these operations result in old column values in row LCRs. The default is to compare old values for all columns.

CREATE_APPLY.name: dbms_apply_adm.create_apply
CREATE_APPLY.body:
queue_name => $1
	, apply_name => $2
	, rule_set_name => NULL
	, message_handler => NULL
	, ddl_handler => NULL
	, apply_user => NULL
	, apply_database_link => NULL
	, apply_tag => '00'
	, apply_captured => FALSE
	, precommit_handler => NULL
	, negative_rule_set_name => NULL
	, source_database => NULL
CREATE_APPLY.bodyNoDefault:
queue_name => $1
	, apply_name => $2
	, rule_set_name => $3
	, message_handler => $4
	, ddl_handler => $5
	, apply_user => $6
	, apply_database_link => $7
	, apply_tag => $8
	, apply_captured => $9
	, precommit_handler => $10
	, negative_rule_set_name => $11
	, source_database => $12
CREATE_APPLY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.CREATE_APPLY(
     queue_name              IN  VARCHAR2,
     apply_name              IN  VARCHAR2,
     rule_set_name           IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
     message_handler         IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
     ddl_handler             IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
     apply_user              IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
     apply_database_link     IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,

     source_database         IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_APPLY.descriptionText: This procedure creates an apply component.

CREATE_OBJECT_DEPENDENCY.name: dbms_apply_adm.create_object_dependency
CREATE_OBJECT_DEPENDENCY.descriptionText: This procedure creates an object dependency. An object dependency is a virtual dependency definition that defines a parent-child relationship between two objects at a destination database.

DELETE_ALL_ERRORS.name: dbms_apply_adm.delete_all_errors
DELETE_ALL_ERRORS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.DELETE_ALL_ERRORS(
   apply_name  IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
DELETE_ALL_ERRORS.descriptionText: This procedure deletes all the error transactions for the specified apply component.

DELETE_ERROR.name: dbms_apply_adm.delete_error
DELETE_ERROR.descriptionText: This procedure deletes the specified error transaction.

DROP_APPLY.name: dbms_apply_adm.drop_apply
DROP_APPLY.descriptionText: This procedure drops an apply component.

DROP_OBJECT_DEPENDENCY.name: dbms_apply_adm.drop_object_dependency
DROP_OBJECT_DEPENDENCY.descriptionText: This procedure drops an object dependency. An object dependency is a virtual dependency definition that defines a parent-child relationship between two objects at a destination database.

EXECUTE_ALL_ERRORS.name: dbms_apply_adm.execute_all_errors
EXECUTE_ALL_ERRORS.descriptionText: This procedure reexecutes the error transactions in the error queue for the specified apply component.

EXECUTE_ERROR.name: dbms_apply_adm.execute_error
EXECUTE_ERROR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.EXECUTE_ERROR(
   local_transaction_id  IN  VARCHAR2,
   execute_as_user       IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE,
   user_procedure        IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
EXECUTE_ERROR.descriptionText: This procedure reexecutes the specified error transaction in the error queue.

GET_ERROR_MESSAGE.name: dbms_apply_adm.get_error_message
GET_ERROR_MESSAGE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.GET_ERROR_MESSAGE(
   message_number          IN   NUMBER, 
   local_transaction_id    IN   VARCHAR2,
   destination_queue_name  OUT  VARCHAR2, 
   execute                 OUT  BOOLEAN)
RETURN ANYDATA;

DBMS_APPLY_ADM.GET_ERROR_MESSAGE(
   message_number          IN   NUMBER, 
   local_transaction_id    IN   VARCHAR2)
RETURN ANYDATA;
GET_ERROR_MESSAGE.descriptionText: This function returns the message payload from the error queue for the specified message number and transaction identifier. The message can be a logical change record (LCR) or a non-LCR message.

REMOVE_STMT_HANDLER.name: dbms_apply_adm.remove_stmt_handler
REMOVE_STMT_HANDLER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.REMOVE_STMT_HANDLER(
   object_name     IN  VARCHAR2,
   operation_name  IN  VARCHAR2,
   handler_name    IN  VARCHAR2,
   apply_name      IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
REMOVE_STMT_HANDLER.descriptionText: This procedure removes a statement DML handler for a specified operation on a specified database object from a single apply component or from all apply components in the database.

SET_CHANGE_HANDLER.name: dbms_apply_adm.set_change_handler
SET_CHANGE_HANDLER.body:
change_table_name => $1
	, source_table_name => $2
	, capture_values => $3
	, apply_name => $4
	, operation_name => $5
	, change_handler_name => NULL
SET_CHANGE_HANDLER.bodyNoDefault:
change_table_name => $1
	, source_table_name => $2
	, capture_values => $3
	, apply_name => $4
	, operation_name => $5
	, change_handler_name => $6
SET_CHANGE_HANDLER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.SET_CHANGE_HANDLER(
   change_table_name    IN  VARCHAR2,
   source_table_name    IN  VARCHAR2,
   capture_values       IN  VARCHAR2,
   apply_name           IN  VARCHAR2,
   operation_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   change_handler_name  IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
SET_CHANGE_HANDLER.descriptionText: This procedure sets or unsets a change handler that tracks changes for a specified operation on a specified database object for a single apply component.

SET_DML_HANDLER.name: dbms_apply_adm.set_dml_handler
SET_DML_HANDLER.body:
object_name => $1
	, object_type => $2
	, operation_name => $3
	, error_handler => FALSE
	, user_procedure => $4
	, apply_database_link => NULL
	, apply_name => NULL
	, assemble_lobs => TRUE
SET_DML_HANDLER.bodyNoDefault:
object_name => $1
	, object_type => $2
	, operation_name => $3
	, error_handler => $4
	, user_procedure => $5
	, apply_database_link => $6
	, apply_name => $7
	, assemble_lobs => $8
SET_DML_HANDLER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.SET_DML_HANDLER(
   object_name          IN  VARCHAR2,
   object_type          IN  VARCHAR2,
   operation_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   error_handler        IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE,
   user_procedure       IN  VARCHAR2,
   apply_database_link  IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   apply_name           IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   assemble_lobs        IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT TRUE);
SET_DML_HANDLER.descriptionText: This procedure sets or unsets a user procedure as a procedure DML handler for a specified operation on a specified database object for a single apply component or for all apply components in the database. The user procedure alters the apply behavior for the specified operation on the specified object.

SET_ENQUEUE_DESTINATION.name: dbms_apply_adm.set_enqueue_destination
SET_ENQUEUE_DESTINATION.descriptionText: This procedure sets the queue where the apply component automatically enqueues a message that satisfies the specified rule.

SET_EXECUTE.name: dbms_apply_adm.set_execute
SET_EXECUTE.descriptionText: This procedure specifies whether a message that satisfies the specified rule is executed by an apply component.

SET_GLOBAL_INSTANTIATION_SCN.name: dbms_apply_adm.set_global_instantiation_scn
SET_GLOBAL_INSTANTIATION_SCN.body:
source_database_name => $1
	, instantiation_scn => $2
	, apply_database_link => NULL
	, recursive => FALSE
	, source_root_name => NULL
SET_GLOBAL_INSTANTIATION_SCN.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.SET_GLOBAL_INSTANTIATION_SCN(
  source_database_name  IN  VARCHAR2,
  instantiation_scn     IN  NUMBER,
  apply_database_link   IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
  recursive             IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE,
  source_root_name      IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
SET_GLOBAL_INSTANTIATION_SCN.descriptionText: This procedure records the specified instantiation SCN for the specified source database and, optionally, for the schemas at the source database and the tables owned by these schemas. This procedure overwrites any existing instantiation SCN for the database, and, if it sets the instantiation SCN for a schema or a table, then it overwrites any existing instantiation SCN for the schema or table.

SET_KEY_COLUMNS.name: dbms_apply_adm.set_key_columns
SET_KEY_COLUMNS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.SET_KEY_COLUMNS(
   object_name          IN  VARCHAR2,
   column_list          IN  VARCHAR2,
   apply_database_link  IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);

DBMS_APPLY_ADM.SET_KEY_COLUMNS(
   object_name          IN  VARCHAR2,
   column_table         IN  DBMS_UTILITY.NAME_ARRAY,
   apply_database_link  IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
SET_KEY_COLUMNS.descriptionText: This procedure records the set of columns to be used as the substitute primary key for apply purposes and removes existing substitute primary key columns for the specified object if they exist.

SET_PARAMETER.name: dbms_apply_adm.set_parameter
SET_PARAMETER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.SET_PARAMETER (
   apply_name  IN  VARCHAR2, 
   parameter   IN  VARCHAR2, 
   value       IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
SET_PARAMETER.descriptionText: This procedure sets an apply parameter to the specified value.

SET_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION_SCN.name: dbms_apply_adm.set_schema_instantiation_scn
SET_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION_SCN.body:
source_schema_name => $1
	, source_database_name => $2
	, instantiation_scn => $3
	, apply_database_link => NULL
	, recursive => FALSE
	, source_root_name => NULL
SET_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION_SCN.bodyNoDefault:
source_schema_name => $1
	, source_database_name => $2
	, instantiation_scn => $3
	, apply_database_link => $4
	, recursive => $5
	, source_root_name => $6
SET_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION_SCN.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.SET_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION_SCN(
  source_schema_name    IN  VARCHAR2,
  source_database_name  IN  VARCHAR2,
  instantiation_scn     IN  NUMBER,
  apply_database_link   IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
  recursive             IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE,
  source_root_name      IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
SET_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION_SCN.descriptionText: This procedure records the specified instantiation SCN for the specified schema in the specified source database and, optionally, for the tables owned by the schema at the source database. This procedure overwrites any existing instantiation SCN for the schema, and, if it sets the instantiation SCN for a table, it overwrites any existing instantiation SCN for the table.

SET_TABLE_INSTANTIATION_SCN.name: dbms_apply_adm.set_table_instantiation_scn
SET_TABLE_INSTANTIATION_SCN.body:
source_object_name => $1
	, source_database_name => $2
	, instantiation_scn => $3
	, apply_database_link => NULL
	, source_root_name => NULL
SET_TABLE_INSTANTIATION_SCN.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.SET_TABLE_INSTANTIATION_SCN(
  source_object_name    IN  VARCHAR2,
  source_database_name  IN  VARCHAR2,
  instantiation_scn     IN  NUMBER,
  apply_database_link   IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
  source_root_name      IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
SET_TABLE_INSTANTIATION_SCN.descriptionText: This procedure records the specified instantiation SCN for the specified table in the specified source database. This procedure overwrites any existing instantiation SCN for the particular table.

SET_UPDATE_CONFLICT_HANDLER.name: dbms_apply_adm.set_update_conflict_handler
SET_UPDATE_CONFLICT_HANDLER.body:
object_name => $1
	, method_name => $2
	, resolution_column => $3
	, column_list => $4
	, apply_database_link => NULL
SET_UPDATE_CONFLICT_HANDLER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.SET_UPDATE_CONFLICT_HANDLER(
   object_name          IN  VARCHAR2,
   method_name          IN  VARCHAR2,
   resolution_column    IN  VARCHAR2,
   column_list          IN  DBMS_UTILITY.NAME_ARRAY,
   apply_database_link  IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
SET_UPDATE_CONFLICT_HANDLER.descriptionText: This procedure adds, modifies, or removes a prebuilt update conflict handler for the specified object.

SET_VALUE_DEPENDENCY.name: dbms_apply_adm.set_value_dependency
SET_VALUE_DEPENDENCY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_APPLY_ADM.SET_VALUE_DEPENDENCY(
   dependency_name IN VARCHAR2,
   object_name     IN VARCHAR2,
   attribute_list  IN VARCHAR2);

DBMS_APPLY_ADM.SET_VALUE_DEPENDENCY(
   dependency_name IN VARCHAR2,
   object_name     IN VARCHAR2,
   attribute_table IN DBMS_UTILITY.NAME_ARRAY);
SET_VALUE_DEPENDENCY.descriptionText: This procedure sets or removes a value dependency. A value dependency is a virtual dependency definition that defines a relationship between the columns of two or more tables.

START_APPLY.name: dbms_apply_adm.start_apply
START_APPLY.descriptionText: This procedure directs the apply component to start applying messages.

STOP_APPLY.name: dbms_apply_adm.stop_apply
STOP_APPLY.descriptionText: This procedure stops the apply component from applying messages and rolls back any unfinished transactions being applied.

BIND_AGENT.name: dbms_aq.bind_agent
BIND_AGENT.descriptionText: This procedure creates an entry for an Oracle Database Advanced Queuing agent in the LDAP server.

DEL_ALIAS_FROM_LDAP.name: dbms_aq.del_alias_from_ldap
DEL_ALIAS_FROM_LDAP.descriptionText: This procedure drops an alias for a queue, agent, or JMS ConnectionFactory in LDAP.

DEQUEUE.name: dbms_aq.dequeue
DEQUEUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQ.DEQUEUE (
   queue_name          IN      VARCHAR2,
   dequeue_options     IN      dequeue_options_t,
   message_properties  OUT     message_properties_t,
   payload             OUT     "<ADT_1>"
   msgid               OUT     RAW);
DEQUEUE.descriptionText: This procedure dequeues a message from the specified queue.

	, message_properties_array => $4
	, payload_array => $5
	, msgid_array => $6
	, error_array => $7
DEQUEUE_ARRAY.bodyNoDefault:
queue_name => $1
	, dequeue_options => $2
	, array_size => $3
	, message_properties_array => $4
	, payload_array => $5
	, msgid_array => $6
	, error_array => $7
DEQUEUE_ARRAY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQ.DEQUEUE_ARRAY (
   queue_name                IN   VARCHAR2,
   dequeue_options           IN   dequeue_options_t,
   array_size                IN   pls_integer,
   message_properties_array  OUT  message_properties_array_t,
   payload_array             OUT  "<COLLECTION_1>",
   msgid_array               OUT  msgid_array_t,
   error_array               OUT  error_array_t)
RETURN pls_integer;
DEQUEUE_ARRAY.descriptionText: This function dequeues an array of messages and returns them in the form of an array of payloads, an array of message properties and an array of message IDs. This function returns the number of messages successfully dequeued.

ENQUEUE.name: dbms_aq.enqueue
ENQUEUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQ.ENQUEUE (
   queue_name          IN      VARCHAR2,
   enqueue_options     IN      enqueue_options_t,
   message_properties  IN      message_properties_t,
   payload             IN       "<ADT_1>",
   msgid               OUT     RAW);
ENQUEUE.descriptionText: This procedure adds a message to the specified queue.

ENQUEUE_ARRAY.name: dbms_aq.enqueue_array
ENQUEUE_ARRAY.body:
queue_name => $1
	, enqueue_options => $2
	, array_size => $3
	, message_properties_array => $4
	, payload_array => $5
	, msgid_array => $6
	, error_array => $7
ENQUEUE_ARRAY.bodyNoDefault:
queue_name => $1
	, enqueue_options => $2
	, array_size => $3
	, message_properties_array => $4
	, payload_array => $5
	, msgid_array => $6
	, error_array => $7
ENQUEUE_ARRAY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQ.ENQUEUE_ARRAY (
   queue_name                IN   VARCHAR2,
   enqueue_options           IN   enqueue_options_t,
   array_size                IN   pls_integer,
   message_properties_array  IN   message_properties_array_t,
   payload_array             IN   "<COLLECTION_1>",
   msgid_array               OUT  msgid_array_t,
   error_array               OUT  error_array_t)
RETURN pls_integer;
ENQUEUE_ARRAY.descriptionText: This function enqueues an array of payloads using a corresponding array of message properties. The output will be an array of message IDs of the enqueued messages.

LISTEN.name: dbms_aq.listen
LISTEN.descriptionText: This procedure listens on one or more queues on behalf of a list of agents. The address field of the agent indicates the queue the agent wants to monitor. Only local queues are supported as addresses. Protocol is reserved for future use.

PLSQLCALLBACK.name: DBMS_AQ.plsqlcallback
PLSQLCALLBACK.bodyFullText:
plsqlcallback(
  context  IN  RAW, 
  reginfo  IN  SYS.AQ$_REG_INFO, 
  descr    IN  SYS.AQ$_DESCRIPTOR, 
  payload  IN  RAW,
  payloadl IN  NUMBER);

POST.name: dbms_aq.post
POST.descriptionText: This procedure posts to a list of anonymous subscriptions that allows all clients who are registered for the subscriptions to get notifications.

REGISTER.name: dbms_aq.register
REGISTER.descriptionText: This procedure registers an e-mail address, user-defined PL/SQL procedure, or HTTP URL for message notification.

UNBIND_AGENT.name: dbms_aq.unbind_agent
UNBIND_AGENT.descriptionText: This procedure removes the entry for an Oracle Database Advanced Queuing agent from the LDAP server.

UNREGISTER.name: dbms_aq.unregister
UNREGISTER.descriptionText: This procedure unregisters a subscription which turns off notifications.

ADD_ALIAS_TO_LDAP.name: dbms_aqadm.add_alias_to_ldap
ADD_ALIAS_TO_LDAP.descriptionText: This procedure creates an alias for a queue, agent, or a JMS ConnectionFactory in LDAP. The alias will be placed directly under the database serve\'s distinguished name in LDAP hierarchy.

ADD_SUBSCRIBER.name: dbms_aqadm.add_subscriber

queue_name => $1
	, subscriber => $2
	, rule => NULL
	, transformation => NULL
	, queue_to_queue => FALSE

ADD_SUBSCRIBER.bodyNoDefault:
queue_name => $1
	, subscriber => $2
	, rule => $3
	, transformation => $4
	, queue_to_queue => $5
	, delivery_mode => $6
ADD_SUBSCRIBER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.ADD_SUBSCRIBER (

   queue_to_queue  IN    BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
   delivery_mode   IN    PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT DBMS_AQADM.PERSISTENT);
ADD_SUBSCRIBER.descriptionText: This procedure adds a default subscriber to a queue.

	, certificate_location => NULL
	, enable_http => FALSE
	, enable_smtp => FALSE
	, enable_anyp => FALSE

DBMS_AQADM.ALTER_AQ_AGENT (

  enable_http               IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
  enable_smtp               IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
  enable_anyp               IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE )
ALTER_AQ_AGENT.descriptionText: This procedure alters an agent registered for Oracle Database Advanced Queuing Internet access. It is also used to alter an Oracle Database Advanced Queuing agent that accesses secure queues.

   queue_name        IN    VARCHAR2,
   max_retries       IN    NUMBER   DEFAULT NULL,

	, comment => NULL
	, primary_instance => NULL

ALTER_SUBSCRIBER.name: dbms_aqadm.alter_subscriber

   subscriber     IN    sys.aq$_agent,

   transformation IN    VARCHAR2);

	, certificate_location => NULL

CREATE_NP_QUEUE.name: dbms_aqadm.create_np_queue
CREATE_NP_QUEUE.bodyFullText:

CREATE_QUEUE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a queue in the specified queue table.

CREATE_QUEUE_TABLE.name: dbms_aqadm.create_queue_table
CREATE_QUEUE_TABLE.body:
queue_table => $1
	, queue_payload_type => $2
	, storage_clause => NULL
	, sort_list => NULL
	, multiple_consumers => FALSE
	, message_grouping => NONE
	, comment => NULL
	, auto_commit => TRUE
	, primary_instance => 0
	, secondary_instance => 0
	, compatible => NULL
	, secure => FALSE
CREATE_QUEUE_TABLE.bodyNoDefault:
queue_table => $1
	, queue_payload_type => $2
	, storage_clause => $3
	, sort_list => $4
	, multiple_consumers => $5
	, message_grouping => $6
	, comment => $7
	, auto_commit => $8
	, primary_instance => $9
	, secondary_instance => $10
	, compatible => $11
	, secure => $12
CREATE_QUEUE_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.CREATE_QUEUE_TABLE (
   queue_table          IN      VARCHAR2,
   queue_payload_type   IN      VARCHAR2,
   storage_clause       IN      VARCHAR2        DEFAULT NULL,
   sort_list            IN      VARCHAR2        DEFAULT NULL,
   multiple_consumers   IN      BOOLEAN         DEFAULT FALSE,
   message_grouping     IN      BINARY_INTEGER  DEFAULT NONE,
   comment              IN      VARCHAR2        DEFAULT NULL,
   auto_commit          IN      BOOLEAN         DEFAULT TRUE,
   primary_instance     IN      BINARY_INTEGER  DEFAULT 0, 
   secondary_instance   IN      BINARY_INTEGER  DEFAULT 0,
   compatible           IN      VARCHAR2        DEFAULT NULL,
   secure               IN      BOOLEAN         DEFAULT FALSE);
CREATE_QUEUE_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a queue table for messages of a predefined type.

CREATE_SHARDED_QUEUE.name: DBMS_AQADM.create_sharded_queue
CREATE_SHARDED_QUEUE.body:
queue_name => $1
	, storage_clause => NULL
	, multiple_consumers => FALSE
	, max_retries => NULL
	, comment => NULL
CREATE_SHARDED_QUEUE.bodyFullText:
CREATE_SHARDED_QUEUE (
    queue_name             IN VARCHAR2,
    storage_clause         IN VARCHAR2       DEFAULT NULL,
    multiple_consumers     IN BOOLEAN        DEFAULT FALSE,
    max_retries            IN NUMBER         DEFAULT NULL,
    comment                IN VARCHAR2       DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_SHARDED_QUEUE.descriptionText: CREATE_SHARDED_QUEUE is a new API in 12c Release 1 (12.1) to create a queue and its queue table as appropriate for a JMS sharded queue. This API cannot be used to create unsharded queues. JMS sharded queues must be created using this single integrated API that will automatically set AQ properties as needed for JMS.

DISABLE_DB_ACCESS.name: dbms_aqadm.disable_db_access
DISABLE_DB_ACCESS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.DISABLE_DB_ACCESS (
  agent_name                IN VARCHAR2,
  db_username               IN VARCHAR2)
DISABLE_DB_ACCESS.descriptionText: This procedure revokes the privileges of a specific database user from an Oracle Database Advanced Queuing Internet agent.

DISABLE_PROPAGATION_SCHEDULE.name: dbms_aqadm.disable_propagation_schedule
DISABLE_PROPAGATION_SCHEDULE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.DISABLE_PROPAGATION_SCHEDULE ( 
   queue_name            IN   VARCHAR2, 
   destination           IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   destination_queue  IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
DISABLE_PROPAGATION_SCHEDULE.descriptionText: This procedure disables a propagation schedule.

DROP_AQ_AGENT.name: dbms_aqadm.drop_aq_agent
DROP_AQ_AGENT.descriptionText: This procedure drops an agent that was previously registered for Oracle Database Advanced Queuing Internet access.

DROP_QUEUE.name: dbms_aqadm.drop_queue
DROP_QUEUE.descriptionText: This procedure drops an existing queue.

DROP_QUEUE_TABLE.name: dbms_aqadm.drop_queue_table
DROP_QUEUE_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.DROP_QUEUE_TABLE (
   queue_table       IN    VARCHAR2,
   force             IN    BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
   auto_commit       IN    BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE);
DROP_QUEUE_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure drops an existing queue table.

DROP_SHARDED_QUEUE.name: dbms_aqadm.drop_sharded_queue
DROP_SHARDED_QUEUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.DROP_SHARDED_QUEUE( 
       queue_name IN VARCHAR2, 
       force      IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE )
DROP_SHARDED_QUEUE.descriptionText: This procedure drops an existing sharded queue from the database queuing system. You must stop the queue before calling DROP_SHARDED_QUEUE. User must stop the queue explicitly if force is set to FALSE before calling DROP_SHARDED_QUEUE. If force is set to TRUE then queue will be stopped internally and then dropped.

ENABLE_DB_ACCESS.name: dbms_aqadm.enable_db_access
ENABLE_DB_ACCESS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.ENABLE_DB_ACCESS (
  agent_name                IN VARCHAR2,
  db_username               IN VARCHAR2)
ENABLE_DB_ACCESS.descriptionText: This procedure grants an Oracle Database Advanced Queuing Internet agent the privileges of a specific database user.

ENABLE_JMS_TYPES.name: dbms_aqadm.enable_jms_types
ENABLE_JMS_TYPES.descriptionText: Enqueue of JMS types and XML types does not work with Oracle Streams Sys.Anydata queues unless you call this procedure after DBMS_STREAMS_ADM.SET_UP_QUEUE. Enabling an Oracle Streams queue for these types may affect import/export of the queue table.

ENABLE_PROPAGATION_SCHEDULE.name: dbms_aqadm.enable_propagation_schedule
ENABLE_PROPAGATION_SCHEDULE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.ENABLE_PROPAGATION_SCHEDULE ( 
   queue_name         IN   VARCHAR2, 
   destination        IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   destination_queue  IN   VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
ENABLE_PROPAGATION_SCHEDULE.descriptionText: This procedure enables a previously disabled propagation schedule.

GET_MAX_STREAMS_POOL.name: dbms_aqadm.get_max_streams_pool
GET_MAX_STREAMS_POOL.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the value of Oracle Database Advanced Queuing maximum streams pool memory limit.

GET_MIN_STREAMS_POOL.name: dbms_aqadm.get_min_streams_pool
GET_MIN_STREAMS_POOL.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the value of Oracle Database Advanced Queuing minimum streams pool memory limit.

GET_WATERMARK.name: dbms_aqadm.get_watermark
GET_WATERMARK.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the value of watermark set by SET_WATERMARK.

GRANT_QUEUE_PRIVILEGE.name: dbms_aqadm.grant_queue_privilege
GRANT_QUEUE_PRIVILEGE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.GRANT_QUEUE_PRIVILEGE (
   privilege        IN    VARCHAR2,
   queue_name       IN    VARCHAR2,
   grantee          IN    VARCHAR2,
   grant_option     IN    BOOLEAN := FALSE);
GRANT_QUEUE_PRIVILEGE.descriptionText: This procedure grants privileges on a queue to users and roles. The privileges are ENQUEUE or DEQUEUE. Initially, only the queue table owner can use this procedure to grant privileges on the queues.

GRANT_SYSTEM_PRIVILEGE.name: dbms_aqadm.grant_system_privilege
GRANT_SYSTEM_PRIVILEGE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.GRANT_SYSTEM_PRIVILEGE (
   privilege         IN    VARCHAR2,
   grantee           IN    VARCHAR2,
   admin_option      IN    BOOLEAN := FALSE);
GRANT_SYSTEM_PRIVILEGE.descriptionText: This procedure grants Oracle Database Advanced Queuing system privileges to users and roles. The privileges are ENQUEUE_ANY, DEQUEUE_ANY, and MANAGE_ANY. Initially, only SYS and SYSTEM can use this procedure successfully.

MIGRATE_QUEUE_TABLE.name: dbms_aqadm.migrate_queue_table
MIGRATE_QUEUE_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure upgrades an 8.0-compatible queue table to an 8.1-compatible or higher queue table, or downgrades an 8.1-compatible or higher queue table to an 8.0-compatible queue table.

PURGE_QUEUE_TABLE.name: dbms_aqadm.purge_queue_table
PURGE_QUEUE_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.PURGE_QUEUE_TABLE(
   queue_table        IN   VARCHAR2,
   purge_condition    IN   VARCHAR2,
   purge_options      IN   aq$_purge_options_t);
PURGE_QUEUE_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure purges messages from queue tables. You can perform various purge operations on both single-consumer and multiconsumer queue tables for persistent and buffered messages.

QUEUE_SUBSCRIBERS.name: dbms_aqadm.queue_subscribers
QUEUE_SUBSCRIBERS.descriptionText: This function returns the subscribers to an 8.0-compatible multiconsumer queue in the PL/SQL index by table collection type DBMS_AQADM.AQ$_subscriber_list_t. Each element of the collection is of type sys.aq$_agent. This functionality is provided for 8.1-compatible queues by the AQ$queue_table_name_S view.

REMOVE_SUBSCRIBER.name: dbms_aqadm.remove_subscriber
REMOVE_SUBSCRIBER.descriptionText: This procedure removes a default subscriber from a queue. This operation takes effect immediately, and the containing transaction is committed. All references to the subscriber in existing messages are removed as part of the operation.

REVOKE_QUEUE_PRIVILEGE.name: dbms_aqadm.revoke_queue_privilege
REVOKE_QUEUE_PRIVILEGE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.REVOKE_QUEUE_PRIVILEGE (
   privilege         IN      VARCHAR2,
   queue_name        IN      VARCHAR2,
   grantee           IN      VARCHAR2);
REVOKE_QUEUE_PRIVILEGE.descriptionText: This procedure revokes privileges on a queue from users and roles. The privileges are ENQUEUE or DEQUEUE.

REVOKE_SYSTEM_PRIVILEGE.name: dbms_aqadm.revoke_system_privilege
REVOKE_SYSTEM_PRIVILEGE.descriptionText: This procedure revokes Oracle Database Advanced Queuing system privileges from users and roles. The privileges are ENQUEUE_ANY, DEQUEUE_ANY and MANAGE_ANY. The ADMIN option for a system privilege cannot be selectively revoked.

SCHEDULE_PROPAGATION.name: dbms_aqadm.schedule_propagation
SCHEDULE_PROPAGATION.body:
queue_name => $1
	, destination => NULL
	, start_time => SYSDATE
	, duration => NULL
	, next_time => NULL
	, latency => 60
	, destination_queue => NULL
SCHEDULE_PROPAGATION.bodyNoDefault:
queue_name => $1
	, destination => $2
	, start_time => $3
	, duration => $4
	, next_time => $5
	, latency => $6
	, destination_queue => $7
SCHEDULE_PROPAGATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.SCHEDULE_PROPAGATION (
   queue_name          IN    VARCHAR2,
   destination         IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   start_time          IN    DATE     DEFAULT SYSDATE,
   duration            IN    NUMBER   DEFAULT NULL,
   next_time           IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   latency             IN    NUMBER   DEFAULT 60,
   destination_queue   IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
SCHEDULE_PROPAGATION.descriptionText: This procedure schedules propagation of messages from a queue to a destination identified by a specific database link.

SET_MAX_STREAMS_POOL.name: dbms_aqadm.set_max_streams_pool
SET_MAX_STREAMS_POOL.descriptionText: This procedure is used for Oracle Database Advanced Queuing to specify and limit maximum streams pool memory use.

SET_MIN_STREAMS_POOL.name: dbms_aqadm.set_min_streams_pool
SET_MIN_STREAMS_POOL.descriptionText: This procedure is used for Oracle Database AQ to specify and limit minimum streams pool memory use.

SET_WATERMARK.name: dbms_aqadm.set_watermark
SET_WATERMARK.descriptionText: This procedure is used for Oracle Database Advanced Queuing notification to specify and limit memory use.

START_QUEUE.name: dbms_aqadm.start_queue
START_QUEUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.START_QUEUE ( 
   queue_name      IN     VARCHAR2,
   enqueue         IN     BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   dequeue         IN     BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE);
START_QUEUE.descriptionText: This procedure enables the specified queue for enqueuing or dequeuing.

STOP_QUEUE.name: dbms_aqadm.stop_queue
STOP_QUEUE.body:
queue_name => $1
	, enqueue => TRUE
	, dequeue => TRUE
	, wait => TRUE
STOP_QUEUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.STOP_QUEUE (   
   queue_name      IN   VARCHAR2,
   enqueue         IN   BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   dequeue         IN   BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   wait            IN   BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE);
STOP_QUEUE.descriptionText: This procedure disables enqueuing or dequeuing on the specified queue.

UNSCHEDULE_PROPAGATION.name: dbms_aqadm.unschedule_propagation
UNSCHEDULE_PROPAGATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.UNSCHEDULE_PROPAGATION (
   queue_name         IN  VARCHAR2,
   destination        IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL
   destination_queue  IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
UNSCHEDULE_PROPAGATION.descriptionText: This procedure unschedules previously scheduled propagation of messages from a queue to a destination identified by a specific database link.

VERIFY_QUEUE_TYPES.name: dbms_aqadm.verify_queue_types
VERIFY_QUEUE_TYPES.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AQADM.VERIFY_QUEUE_TYPES (
   src_queue_name    IN    VARCHAR2,
   dest_queue_name   IN    VARCHAR2,
   destination       IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   rc                OUT   BINARY_INTEGER);
VERIFY_QUEUE_TYPES.descriptionText: This procedure verifies that the source and destination queues have identical types. The result of the verification is stored in the table sys.aq$_message_types, overwriting all previous output of this command.

SET_MAILHOST.name: dbms_aqelm.set_mailhost
SET_MAILHOST.descriptionText: This procedure sets the host name for the SMTP server. The database uses this SMTP server host name to send out e-mail notifications.

SET_MAILPORT.name: dbms_aqelm.set_mailport
SET_MAILPORT.descriptionText: This procedure sets the port number for the SMTP server.

SET_SENDFROM.name: dbms_aqelm.set_sendfrom
SET_SENDFROM.descriptionText: This procedure sets the sent-from e-mail address. This e-mail address is used in the sent-from field in all the e-mail notifications sent out by the database to the registered e-mail addresses.

ENQUOTE_LITERAL.name: dbms_assert.enquote_literal
ENQUOTE_LITERAL.descriptionText: This function adds leading and trailing single quotes to a string literal.

ENQUOTE_NAME.name: dbms_assert.enquote_name
ENQUOTE_NAME.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ASSERT.ENQUOTE_NAME (
   str            VARCHAR2, 
   capitalize     BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE)
RETURN VARCHAR2;
ENQUOTE_NAME.descriptionText: This function encloses the provided string within quotation marks. However, additional quotation marks are not added if the string is already in quotation marks. The quoted string is then checked to see if it is a valid identifier.

NOOP.name: dbms_assert.noop
NOOP.descriptionText: This function returns the value without any checking.

QUALIFIED_SQL_NAME.name: dbms_assert.qualified_sql_name
QUALIFIED_SQL_NAME.descriptionText: This function verifies that the input string is a qualified SQL name.

SCHEMA_NAME.name: dbms_assert.schema_name
SCHEMA_NAME.descriptionText: This function verifies that the input string is an existing schema name.

SIMPLE_SQL_NAME.name: dbms_assert.simple_sql_name
SIMPLE_SQL_NAME.descriptionText: This function verifies that the input string is a simple SQL name.

SQL_OBJECT_NAME.name: dbms_assert.sql_object_name
SQL_OBJECT_NAME.descriptionText: This function verifies that the input parameter string is a qualified SQL identifier of an existing SQL object.

CLEAN_AUDIT_TRAIL.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.clean_audit_trail
CLEAN_AUDIT_TRAIL.body:
audit_trail_type => $1
	, use_last_arch_timestamp => TRUE
	, container => CONTAINER_CURRENT
	, database_id => NULL
	, container_guid => NULL
CLEAN_AUDIT_TRAIL.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.CLEAN_AUDIT_TRAIL(
   audit_trail_type         IN PLS_INTEGER,
   use_last_arch_timestamp  IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   container                IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT CONTAINER_CURRENT,
   database_id              IN NUMBER DEFAULT NULL,
   container_guid           IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CLEAN_AUDIT_TRAIL.descriptionText: This procedure deletes audit trail records. The CLEAN_AUDIT_TRAIL procedure is usually called after the SET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP Procedure has been used to set the last archived timestamp for the audit records.

CLEAR_AUDIT_TRAIL_PROPERTY.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.clear_audit_trail_property
CLEAR_AUDIT_TRAIL_PROPERTY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.CLEAR_AUDIT_TRAIL_PROPERTY(
   audit_trail_type        IN PLS_INTEGER,
   audit_trail_property    IN PLS_INTEGER,
   use_default_values      IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE) ;
CLEAR_AUDIT_TRAIL_PROPERTY.descriptionText: This procedure clears the value for the audit trail property that is specified. Audit trail properties are set using the SET_AUDIT_TRAIL_PROPERTY Procedure.

CLEAR_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.clear_last_archive_timestamp
CLEAR_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.body:
audit_trail_type => $1
	, rac_instance_number => NULL
	, container => CONTAINER_CURRENT
	, database_id => NULL
	, container_guid => NULL
CLEAR_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.CLEAR_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP(
   audit_trail_type         IN PLS_INTEGER,
   rac_instance_number      IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT NULL,
   container                IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT CONTAINER_CURRENT,
   database_id              IN NUMBER DEFAULT NULL,
   container_guid           IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CLEAR_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.descriptionText: This procedure clears the timestamp set by the SET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP Procedure.

CREATE_PURGE_JOB.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.create_purge_job
CREATE_PURGE_JOB.body:
audit_trail_type => $1
	, audit_trail_purge_interval => $2
	, audit_trail_purge_name => $3
	, use_last_arch_timestamp => TRUE
	, container => CONTAINER_CURRENT
CREATE_PURGE_JOB.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.CREATE_PURGE_JOB(
   audit_trail_type            IN PLS_INTEGER,
   audit_trail_purge_interval  IN PLS_INTEGER,
   audit_trail_purge_name      IN VARCHAR2,
   use_last_arch_timestamp     IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   container                   IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT CONTAINER_CURRENT) ;
CREATE_PURGE_JOB.descriptionText: This procedure creates a purge job for periodically deleting the audit trail records.

DEINIT_CLEANUP.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.deinit_cleanup
DEINIT_CLEANUP.descriptionText: This procedure undoes the setup and initialization performed by the INIT_CLEANUP Procedure. The DEINIT_CLEANUP procedure clears the value of the default_cleanup_interval parameter. However, when used for audit tables, it does not move the audit trail tables back to their original tablespace.

DROP_OLD_UNIFIED_AUDIT_TABLES.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.drop_old_unified_audit_tables
DROP_OLD_UNIFIED_AUDIT_TABLES.descriptionText: This procedure drops old unified audit tables following the cloning of a pluggable database (PDB).

DROP_PURGE_JOB.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.drop_purge_job
DROP_PURGE_JOB.descriptionText: This procedure drops the purge job created using the CREATE_PURGE_JOB Procedure. The name of the purge job is passed as an argument.

FLUSH_UNIFIED_AUDIT_TRAIL.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.flush_unified_audit_trail
FLUSH_UNIFIED_AUDIT_TRAIL.descriptionText: This procedure writes the unified audit trail records in the SGA queue to disk.

GET_AUDIT_COMMIT_DELAY.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.get_audit_commit_delay
GET_AUDIT_COMMIT_DELAY.descriptionText: This function returns the audit commit delay time as the number of seconds. audit commit delay time is the maximum time that it takes to COMMIT an audit record to the database audit trail. If it takes more time to COMMIT an audit record than defined by the audit commit delay time, then a copy of the audit record is written to the operating system (OS) audit trail.

GET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.get_last_archive_timestamp
GET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.GET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP(
   audit_trail_type         IN PLS_INTEGER,
   audit_trail_property     IN PLS_INTEGER)
 RETURN NUMBER;
GET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.descriptionText: This procedure returns the property value set by the SET_AUDIT_TRAIL_PROPERTY Procedure.

INIT_CLEANUP.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.init_cleanup
INIT_CLEANUP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.INIT_CLEANUP(
   audit_trail_type          IN PLS_INTEGER,
   default_cleanup_interval  IN PLS_INTEGER
   container                 IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT CONTAINER_CURRENT);
INIT_CLEANUP.descriptionText: This procedure sets up the audit management infrastructure and a default cleanup interval for the audit trail records. If the audit trail tables are in the SYSTEM tablespace, then the procedure moves them to the SYSAUX tablespace. If you are using unified auditing, you do not need to run this procedure because the unified audit trail tables are in the SYSAUX tablespace by default. If you are not using unified auditing, refer to Oracle Database Upgrade Guide for documentation which references an environment without unified auditing.

IS_CLEANUP_INITIALIZED.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.is_cleanup_initialized
IS_CLEANUP_INITIALIZED.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.IS_CLEANUP_INITIALIZED(
   audit_trail_type  IN PLS_INTEGER
   container         IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT CONTAINER_CURRENT)
 RETURN BOOLEAN;
IS_CLEANUP_INITIALIZED.descriptionText: This function checks to see if the INIT_CLEANUP Procedure has been run for an audit trail type. The IS_CLEANUP_INITIALIZED function returns TRUE if the procedure has already been run for the audit trail type. It returns FALSE if the procedure has not been run for the audit trail type.

LOAD_UNIFIED_AUDIT_FILES.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.load_unified_audit_files
LOAD_UNIFIED_AUDIT_FILES.descriptionText: This procedure loads the data from the spillover OS audit files in a unified audit trail into the designated unified audit trail tablespace.

SET_AUDIT_TRAIL_LOCATION.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.set_audit_trail_location
SET_AUDIT_TRAIL_LOCATION.descriptionText: This procedure moves the audit trail tables from their current tablespace to a user-specified tablespace.

SET_AUDIT_TRAIL_PROPERTY.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.set_audit_trail_property
SET_AUDIT_TRAIL_PROPERTY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.SET_AUDIT_TRAIL_PROPERTY(
   audit_trail_type            IN PLS_INTEGER,
   audit_trail_property        IN PLS_INTEGER,
   audit_trail_property_value  IN PLS_INTEGER) ;
SET_AUDIT_TRAIL_PROPERTY.descriptionText: This procedure sets an audit trail property for the audit trail type that is specified.

SET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.set_last_archive_timestamp
SET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.body:
audit_trail_type => $1
	, last_archive_time => $2
	, rac_instance_number => NULL
	, container => CONTAINER_CURRENT
	, database_id => NULL
	, container_guid => NULL
SET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.bodyNoDefault:
audit_trail_type => $1
	, last_archive_time => $2
	, rac_instance_number => $3
	, container => $4
	, database_id => $5
	, container_guid => $6
SET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUDIT_MGMT.SET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP(
   audit_trail_type         IN PLS_INTEGER,
   last_archive_time        IN TIMESTAMP,
   rac_instance_number      IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT NULL,
   container                IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT CONTAINER_CURRENT,
   database_id              IN NUMBER DEFAULT NULL,
   container_guid           IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
SET_LAST_ARCHIVE_TIMESTAMP.descriptionText: This procedure sets a timestamp indicating when the audit records were last archived. The audit administrator provides the timestamp to be attached to the audit records. The CLEAN_AUDIT_TRAIL Procedure uses this timestamp to decide on the audit records to be deleted.

SET_PURGE_JOB_INTERVAL.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.set_purge_job_interval
SET_PURGE_JOB_INTERVAL.descriptionText: This procedure sets the interval at which the CLEAN_AUDIT_TRAIL Procedure is called for the purge job specified. The purge job must have already been created using the CREATE_PURGE_JOB Procedure.

SET_PURGE_JOB_STATUS.name: dbms_audit_mgmt.set_purge_job_status
SET_PURGE_JOB_STATUS.descriptionText: This procedure enables or disables the specified purge job. The purge job must have already been created using the CREATE_PURGE_JOB Procedure.

FINISH_REPORT_CAPTURE.name: dbms_auto_report.finish_report_capture
FINISH_REPORT_CAPTURE.descriptionText: This procedure ends the complete capture of SQL monitor data that was started with the START_REPORT_CAPTURE Procedure. This subprogram runs a last capture cycle immediately to capture any new data and then ends the per-minute complete capture.

REPORT_REPOSITORY_DETAIL.name: dbms_auto_report.report_repository_detail
REPORT_REPOSITORY_DETAIL.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUTO_REPORT.REPORT_REPOSITORY_DETAIL (
   rid              IN NUMBER    DEFAULT NULL,
   type             IN VARCHAR2  DEFAULT 'XML',
   base_path        IN VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL)
 RETURNS CLOB
REPORT_REPOSITORY_DETAIL.descriptionText: This procedure obtains the stored report for a given report ID in the specified format such as XML or HTML.

REPORT_REPOSITORY_DETAIL_XML.name: dbms_auto_report.report_repository_detail_xml
REPORT_REPOSITORY_DETAIL_XML.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUTO_REPORT.REPORT_REPOSITORY_DETAIL_XML (
   rid              IN NUMBER    DEFAULT NULL,
   base_path        IN VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL)
 RETURNS XMLTYPE
REPORT_REPOSITORY_DETAIL_XML.descriptionText: This procedure obtains the stored XML report for a given report ID.

REPORT_REPOSITORY_LIST_XML.name: dbms_auto_report.report_repository_list_xml
REPORT_REPOSITORY_LIST_XML.body:
active_since => NULL
	, active_upto => NULL
	, snapshot_id => NULL
	, dbid => NULL
	, inst_id => NULL
	, con_dbid => NULL
	, session_id => NULL
	, session_serial => NULL
	, component_name => NULL
	, key1 => NULL
	, key2 => NULL
	, key3 => NULL
	, report_level => 'TYPICAL'
	, base_path => NULL
REPORT_REPOSITORY_LIST_XML.bodyNoDefault:
active_since => $1
	, active_upto => $2
	, snapshot_id => $3
	, dbid => $4
	, inst_id => $5
	, con_dbid => $6
	, session_id => $7
	, session_serial => $8
	, component_name => $9

REPORT_REPOSITORY_LIST_XML.bodyFullText:
DBMS_AUTO_REPORT.REPORT_REPOSITORY_LIST_XML (
    active_since              IN DATE     DEFAULT NULL,
    active_upto               IN DATE     DEFAULT NULL,

REPORT_REPOSITORY_LIST_XML.descriptionText: This procedure obtains an XML report of the list of SQL Monitor and Real-time ADDM data captured in AWR. The input parameters can be used to select and restrict which captured data will be included in the list report. All parameters are optional.

START_REPORT_CAPTURE.name: dbms_auto_report.start_report_capture
START_REPORT_CAPTURE.descriptionText: This procedure captures SQL monitor data of any newly monitored SQLs every minute since the last run of the capture cycle, and stores it in AWR. Every capture cycle attempts to capture data for SQLs that are not currently executing or queued. This is a complete capture since data of all newly monitored SQLs is captured. It continues to run every minute until it is explicitly ended with the FINISH_REPORT_CAPTURE Procedure. In the case of a RAC system, the capture will start on each node of the cluster.

EXECUTE_AUTO_TUNING_TASK.descriptionText: This function and procedure executes the Automatic SQL Tuning task (SYS_AUTO_SQL_TUNING_TASK). Both the function and the procedure run in the context of a new task execution. The difference is that the function returns that new execution name. Note that only SYS can invoke this subprogram.

DISABLE.name: dbms_auto_task_admin.disable
DISABLE.descriptionText: This procedure prevents AUTOTASK from executing any requests from a specified client or operation.

ENABLE.name: dbms_auto_task_admin.enable
ENABLE.descriptionText: This procedure allows a previously disabled client, operation, target type, or individual target to be enabled under AUTOTASK control. Specifying the DEFERRED option postpones the effect of the call until the start of the next maintenance window. If IMMEDIATE option is specified the effect of this call is immediate  as long as there is a currently open maintenance window.

ANALYZE.name: dbms_aw_stats.analyze
ANALYZE.descriptionText: This procedure generates optimizer statistics on a cube or a cube dimension. These statistics are used to generate some execution plans, as described in "Using DBMS_AW_STATS".

CLEAR.name: dbms_aw_stats.clear
CLEAR.descriptionText: Clears the statistics generated by the ANALYZE Procedure.

ABORT_GLOBAL_INSTANTIATION.name: dbms_capture_adm.abort_global_instantiation
ABORT_GLOBAL_INSTANTIATION.descriptionText: This procedure reverses the effects of running the PREPARE_GLOBAL_INSTANTIATION, PREPARE_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION, and PREPARE_TABLE_INSTANTIATION procedures.

ABORT_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION.name: dbms_capture_adm.abort_schema_instantiation
ABORT_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION.descriptionText: This procedure reverses the effects of running the PREPARE_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION procedure. It also reverses the effects of running the PREPARE_TABLE_INSTANTIATION procedure on tables in the specified schema.

ABORT_SYNC_INSTANTIATION.name: dbms_capture_adm.abort_sync_instantiation
ABORT_SYNC_INSTANTIATION.descriptionText: This procedure reverses the effects of running the PREPARE_SYNC_INSTANTIATION procedure. Specifically, this procedure removes data dictionary information related to the table instantiation.

ABORT_TABLE_INSTANTIATION.name: dbms_capture_adm.abort_table_instantiation
ABORT_TABLE_INSTANTIATION.descriptionText: This procedure reverses the effects of running the PREPARE_TABLE_INSTANTIATION procedure.

INCLUDE_EXTRA_ATTRIBUTE.descriptionText: This procedure includes or excludes an extra attribute in logical change records (LCRs) captured by the specified capture process or synchronous capture.

PREPARE_GLOBAL_INSTANTIATION.name: dbms_capture_adm.prepare_global_instantiation
PREPARE_GLOBAL_INSTANTIATION.descriptionText: This procedure performs the synchronization necessary for instantiating all the tables in the database at another database and can enable supplemental logging for key columns or all columns in these tables. This procedure prepares the tables in the database for instantiation when a capture process will be used to capture changes to the tables in the database.

PREPARE_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION.name: dbms_capture_adm.prepare_schema_instantiation
PREPARE_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_CAPTURE_ADM.PREPARE_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION(
   schema_name           IN  VARCHAR2,
   supplemental_logging  IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT 'KEYS',
   container             IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT 'CURRENT');
PREPARE_SCHEMA_INSTANTIATION.descriptionText: This procedure performs the synchronization necessary for instantiating all tables in the schema at another database and can enable supplemental logging for key columns or all columns in these tables. This procedure prepares the tables in the schema for instantiation when a capture process will be used to capture changes to the tables in the schema.

PREPARE_SYNC_INSTANTIATION.name: dbms_capture_adm.prepare_sync_instantiation
PREPARE_SYNC_INSTANTIATION.descriptionText: This function performs the synchronization necessary for instantiating one or more tables at another database. This function returns the prepare system change number (SCN) for the table or tables being prepared for instantiation.

PREPARE_TABLE_INSTANTIATION.name: dbms_capture_adm.prepare_table_instantiation
PREPARE_TABLE_INSTANTIATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_CAPTURE_ADM.PREPARE_TABLE_INSTANTIATION(
   table_name            IN  VARCHAR2,
   supplemental_logging  IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT 'KEYS',
   container             IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT 'CURRENT');
PREPARE_TABLE_INSTANTIATION.descriptionText: This procedure performs the synchronization necessary for instantiating the table at another database and can enable supplemental logging for key columns or all columns in the table. This procedure prepares the table for instantiation when a capture process will be used to capture changes to the table.

SET_PARAMETER.descriptionText: This procedure sets a capture process parameter to the specified value.

START_CAPTURE.name: dbms_capture_adm.start_capture
START_CAPTURE.descriptionText: This procedure starts the capture process, which mines redo logs and enqueues the mined redo information into the associated queue.

STOP_CAPTURE.name: dbms_capture_adm.stop_capture
STOP_CAPTURE.descriptionText: This procedure stops the capture process from mining redo logs.

   session_cached_cursors   IN NUMBER   DEFAULT 20,
   inactivity_timeout       IN NUMBER   DEFAULT 300,
   max_think_time           IN NUMBER   DEFAULT 120,
   max_use_session          IN NUMBER   DEFAULT 500000,
   max_lifetime_session     IN NUMBER   DEFAULT 86400,
   num_cbrok                IN NUMBER   DEFAULT 1,
   maxconn_cbrok            IN NUMBER   DEFAULT 40000);
CONFIGURE_POOL.descriptionText: This procedure configures the pool with advanced options.

RESTORE_DEFAULTS.name: dbms_connection_pool.restore_defaults
RESTORE_DEFAULTS.descriptionText: This procedure restores the pool to default settings.

START_POOL.name: dbms_connection_pool.start_pool
START_POOL.descriptionText: This procedure starts the pool for operations. It is only after this call that the pool could be used by connection classes for creating sessions.

STOP_POOL.name: dbms_connection_pool.stop_pool
STOP_POOL.descriptionText: This procedure stops the pool and makes it unavailable for the registered connection classes.

CQ_NOTIFICATION_QUERYID.name: dbms_cq_notification.cq_notification_queryid
CQ_NOTIFICATION_QUERYID.descriptionText: This function returns the queryid of the most recent query that was attempted to be registered in a registration block.

DEREGISTER.name: dbms_cq_notification.deregister
DEREGISTER.descriptionText: This procedure desubscribes the client with the specified registration identifier (ID).

ENABLE_REG.name: dbms_cq_notification.enable_reg
ENABLE_REG.descriptionText: This procedure adds objects to an existing registration identifier (ID). It is similar to the interface for creating a new registration, except that it takes an existing regid to which to add objects.Subsequent execution of queries causes the objects referenced in the queries to be added to the specified regid, and the registration is completed on invoking the REG_END Procedure.

NEW_REG_START.name: dbms_cq_notification.new_reg_start
NEW_REG_START.descriptionText: This procedure begins a new registration block. Any objects referenced by queries executed within the registration block are considered interesting objects and added to the registration. The registration block ends upon calling the REG_END procedure.

REG_END.name: dbms_cq_notification.reg_end
REG_END.descriptionText: This procedure marks the end of the registration block. No newly executed queries are tracked.

SET_ROWID_THRESHOLD.name: dbms_cq_notification.set_rowid_threshold
SET_ROWID_THRESHOLD.descriptionText: This procedure configures the maximum number of rows of a table published in a change notification if the rows of the table are modified in a transaction.

CREATE_CREDENTIAL.name: dbms_credential.create_credential
CREATE_CREDENTIAL.body:

	, username => $2
	, password => $3
	, database_role => NULL
	, windows_domain => NULL

DBMS_CREDENTIAL.CREATE_CREDENTIAL (

   windows_domain    IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   comments          IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   enabled           IN  BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE);
CREATE_CREDENTIAL.descriptionText: This procedure creates a stored username/password pair in a database object called an Oracle credential.

DISABLE_CREDENTIAL.name: dbms_credential.disable_credential
DISABLE_CREDENTIAL.descriptionText: This procedure disables an Oracle credential.

DROP_CREDENTIAL.name: dbms_credential.drop_credential
DROP_CREDENTIAL.descriptionText: This procedure drops an Oracle credential.

ENABLE_CREDENTIAL.name: dbms_credential.enable_credential
ENABLE_CREDENTIAL.descriptionText: This procedure enables an Oracle credential.

DBMS_CREDENTIAL.UPDATE_CREDENTIAL (
