   buffer      IN           VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET);
FRAGMENT_REPLACE.descriptionText: This procedure replaces the data at the specified offset with the specified data (not to exceed 32k).

FREETEMPORARY.name: dbms_lob.freetemporary
FREETEMPORARY.descriptionText: This procedure frees the temporary BLOB or CLOB in the default temporary tablespace.

GET_DBFS_LINK.name: dbms_lob.get_dbfs_link
GET_DBFS_LINK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc             IN     BLOB,
  storage_path        OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  lob_length          OUT NUMBER);

DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc             IN     CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  storage_path        OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  lob_length          OUT NUMBER);
GET_DBFS_LINK.descriptionText: This function returns the DBFS path name for the specified SecureFile LOB.

GET_DBFS_LINK_STATE.name: dbms_lob.get_dbfs_link_state
GET_DBFS_LINK_STATE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK_STATE (
  lob_loc       IN BLOB,
  storage_path  OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  state         OUT NUMBER,
  cached        OUT BOOLEAN);

DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK_STATE (
  lob_loc       IN CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  storage_path  OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  state         OUT NUMBER,
  cached        OUT BOOLEAN);
GET_DBFS_LINK_STATE.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the current link state of the specified SecureFile.

GET_STORAGE_LIMIT.name: dbms_lob.get_storage_limit
GET_STORAGE_LIMIT.descriptionText: This function returns the LOB storage limit for the specified LOB.

GETCHUNKSIZE.name: dbms_lob.getchunksize
GETCHUNKSIZE.descriptionText: When creating the table, you can specify the chunking factor, a multiple of tablespace blocks in bytes. This corresponds to the chunk size used by the LOB data layer when accessing or modifying the LOB value. Part of the chunk is used to store system-related information, and the rest stores the LOB value.

GETCONTENTTYPE.name: dbms_lob.getcontenttype
GETCONTENTTYPE.descriptionText: This procedure returns the content type string previously set by means of the SETCONTENTTYPE Procedure.

GETLENGTH.name: dbms_lob.getlength
GETLENGTH.descriptionText: This function gets the length of the specified LOB. The length in bytes or characters is returned.

GETOPTIONS.name: dbms_lob.getoptions
GETOPTIONS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.GETOPTIONS (
   lob_loc             IN     BLOB,
   option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER) 
 RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
 
DBMS_LOB.GETOPTIONS (
  lob_loc             IN     CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER) 
RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
GETOPTIONS.descriptionText: This function obtains compression, deduplication, and encryption settings corresponding to the option_type field for a particular LOB.

INSTR.name: dbms_lob.instr
INSTR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.INSTR (
   lob_loc    IN   BLOB,
   pattern    IN   RAW,
   offset     IN   INTEGER := 1,
   nth        IN   INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER;

DBMS_LOB.INSTR (
   lob_loc    IN   CLOB      CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   pattern    IN   VARCHAR2  CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET,
   offset     IN   INTEGER := 1,
   nth        IN   INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER;

DBMS_LOB.INSTR (
   file_loc   IN   BFILE,
   pattern    IN   RAW,
   offset     IN   INTEGER := 1,
   nth        IN   INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER;
INSTR.descriptionText: This function returns the matching position of the nth occurrence of the pattern in the LOB, starting from the offset you specify.

ISOPEN.name: dbms_lob.isopen
ISOPEN.descriptionText: This function checks to see if the LOB was already opened using the input locator. This subprogram is for internal and external LOBs.

ISTEMPORARY.name: dbms_lob.istemporary
ISTEMPORARY.descriptionText: This function determines whether a LOB instance is temporary.

LOADBLOBFROMFILE.name: dbms_lob.loadblobfromfile
LOADBLOBFROMFILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.LOADBLOBFROMFILE (
   dest_lob    IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB, 
   src_bfile   IN            BFILE, 
   amount      IN            INTEGER, 
   dest_offset IN OUT        INTEGER, 
   src_offset  IN OUT        INTEGER);
LOADBLOBFROMFILE.descriptionText: This procedure loads data from BFILE to internal BLOB. This achieves the same outcome as LOADFROMFILE, and returns the new offsets.

LOADCLOBFROMFILE.name: dbms_lob.loadclobfromfile
LOADCLOBFROMFILE.body:
dest_lob => $1
	, src_bfile => $2
	, amount => $3
	, dest_offset => $4
	, src_offset => $5
	, bfile_csid => $6
	, lang_context => $7
	, warning => $8
LOADCLOBFROMFILE.bodyNoDefault:
dest_lob => $1
	, src_bfile => $2
	, amount => $3
	, dest_offset => $4
	, src_offset => $5
	, bfile_csid => $6
	, lang_context => $7
	, warning => $8
LOADCLOBFROMFILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.LOADCLOBFROMFILE (
   dest_lob       IN OUT NOCOPY   NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS, 
   src_bfile      IN              BFILE, 
   amount         IN              INTEGER, 
   dest_offset    IN OUT          INTEGER, 
   src_offset     IN OUT          INTEGER,
   bfile_csid     IN              NUMBER,
   lang_context   IN OUT          INTEGER,
   warning        OUT             INTEGER);
LOADCLOBFROMFILE.descriptionText: This procedure loads data from a BFILE to an internal CLOB/NCLOB with necessary character set conversion and returns the new offsets.

LOADFROMFILE.name: dbms_lob.loadfromfile
LOADFROMFILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.LOADFROMFILE (
   dest_lob    IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB, 
   src_file    IN            BFILE, 
   amount      IN            INTEGER, 
   dest_offset IN            INTEGER  := 1, 
   src_offset  IN            INTEGER  := 1);
LOADFROMFILE.descriptionText: This procedure copies all, or a part of, a source external LOB (BFILE) to a destination internal LOB.

MOVE_TO_DBFS_LINK.name: dbms_lob.move_to_dbfs_link
MOVE_TO_DBFS_LINK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.MOVE_TO_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc       IN OUT BLOB,
  storage_path  IN     VARCHAR2(dbfs_link_path_max_size),
  flags         IN     BINARY INTEGER DEFAULT DBFS_LINK_NOCACHE); 

DBMS_LOB.MOVE_TO_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc       IN OUT CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  storage_path  IN     VARCHAR2(dbfs_link_path_max_size),
  flags         IN     BINARY INTEGER DEFAULT DBFS_LINK_NOCACHE);
MOVE_TO_DBFS_LINK.descriptionText: This procedure archives the specified LOB data (from the database) into the DBFS HSM Store.

OPEN.name: dbms_lob.open
OPEN.descriptionText: This procedure opens a LOB, internal or external, in the indicated mode. Valid modes include read-only, and read/write.

READ.name: dbms_lob.read
READ.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.READ (
   lob_loc   IN             BLOB,
   amount    IN OUT  NOCOPY INTEGER,
   offset    IN             INTEGER,
   buffer    OUT            RAW);

DBMS_LOB.READ (
   lob_loc   IN             CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount    IN OUT  NOCOPY INTEGER,
   offset    IN             INTEGER,
   buffer    OUT            VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET); 

DBMS_LOB.READ (
   file_loc   IN             BFILE,
   amount    IN OUT   NOCOPY INTEGER,
   offset    IN              INTEGER,
   buffer    OUT             RAW);
READ.descriptionText: This procedure reads a piece of a LOB, and returns the specified amount into the buffer parameter, starting from an absolute offset from the beginning of the LOB.

SET_DBFS_LINK.name: dbms_lob.set_dbfs_link
SET_DBFS_LINK.descriptionText: This function links the specified SecureFile to the specified path name. It does not copy the data to the path.

SETCONTENTTYPE.name: dbms_lob.setcontenttype
SETCONTENTTYPE.descriptionText: This procedure sets the content type string for the data in the LOB.

SETOPTIONS.name: dbms_lob.setoptions
SETOPTIONS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.SETOPTIONS (
   lob_loc             IN     BLOB,
   option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER,
   options             IN     PLS_INTEGER);
 
DBMS_LOB.SETOPTIONS (
  lob_loc             IN     CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER, 
  options             IN     PLS_INTEGER);
SETOPTIONS.descriptionText: This procedure enables/disables compression and deduplication on a per-LOB basis, overriding the default LOB column settings.

SUBSTR.name: dbms_lob.substr
SUBSTR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.SUBSTR (
   lob_loc     IN    BLOB,
   amount      IN    INTEGER := 32767,
   offset      IN    INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN RAW;

DBMS_LOB.SUBSTR (
   lob_loc     IN    CLOB   CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount      IN    INTEGER := 32767,
   offset      IN    INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET;

DBMS_LOB.SUBSTR (
   file_loc     IN    BFILE,
   amount      IN    INTEGER := 32767,
   offset      IN    INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN RAW;
SUBSTR.descriptionText: This function returns amount bytes or characters of a LOB, starting from an absolute offset from the beginning of the LOB.

TRIM.name: dbms_lob.trim
TRIM.descriptionText: This procedure trims the value of the internal LOB to the length you specify in the newlen parameter. Specify the length in bytes for BLOBs, and specify the length in characters for CLOBs.

WRITE.name: dbms_lob.write
WRITE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.WRITE (
   lob_loc  IN OUT NOCOPY  BLOB,
   amount   IN             INTEGER,
   offset   IN             INTEGER,
   buffer   IN             RAW);

DBMS_LOB.WRITE (
   lob_loc  IN OUT  NOCOPY CLOB   CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount   IN             INTEGER,
   offset   IN             INTEGER,
   buffer   IN             VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET);
WRITE.descriptionText: This procedure writes a specified amount of data into an internal LOB, starting from an absolute offset from the beginning of the LOB. The data is written from the buffer parameter.

WRITEAPPEND.name: dbms_lob.writeappend
WRITEAPPEND.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.WRITEAPPEND (
   lob_loc IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB, 
   amount  IN            INTEGER, 
   buffer  IN            RAW); 

DBMS_LOB.WRITEAPPEND (
   lob_loc IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS, 
   amount  IN            INTEGER, 
   buffer  IN            VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET);
WRITEAPPEND.descriptionText: This procedure writes a specified amount of data to the end of an internal LOB. The data is written from the buffer parameter.

UNSUBSCRIBE_USER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.UNSUBSCRIBE_USER(
                LD IN RAW 
        USER_HANDLE IN RAW 
        SERVICE_HANDLE IN RAW 
)
return BINARY_INTEGER

GET_DEDUPLICATE_REGIONS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.GET_DEDUPLICATE_REGIONS(
        LOB_LOC IN BLOB 
        REGION_TABLE IN/OUT PL/SQL TABLE 
)

ALLOCATE_UNIQUE.name: dbms_lock.allocate_unique
ALLOCATE_UNIQUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOCK.ALLOCATE_UNIQUE (
   lockname         IN  VARCHAR2,
   lockhandle       OUT VARCHAR2,
   expiration_secs  IN  INTEGER   DEFAULT 864000);
ALLOCATE_UNIQUE.descriptionText: This procedure allocates a unique lock identifier (in the range of 1073741824 to 1999999999) a specified lock name. Lock identifiers are used to enable applications to coordinate their use of locks. This is provided because it may be easier for applications to coordinate their use of locks based on lock names rather than lock numbers.

CONVERT.name: dbms_lock.convert
CONVERT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOCK.CONVERT(
   id         IN INTEGER || 
   lockhandle IN VARCHAR2,
   lockmode   IN INTEGER,
   timeout    IN NUMBER DEFAULT MAXWAIT)
  RETURN INTEGER;
CONVERT.descriptionText: This function converts a lock from one mode to another. CONVERT is an overloaded function that accepts either a user-defined lock identifier, or the lock handle returned by the ALLOCATE_UNIQUE procedure.

RELEASE.name: dbms_lock.release
RELEASE.descriptionText: This function explicitly releases a lock previously acquired using the REQUEST function. Locks are automatically released at the end of a session. RELEASE is an overloaded function that accepts either a user-defined lock identifier, or the lock handle returned by the ALLOCATE_UNIQUE procedure.

REQUEST.name: dbms_lock.request
REQUEST.body:
id => $1
	, lockhandle => $2
	, lockmode => X_MODE
	, timeout => MAXWAIT
	, release_on_commit => FALSE
REQUEST.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOCK.REQUEST(
   id                 IN  INTEGER ||
   lockhandle         IN  VARCHAR2,
   lockmode           IN  INTEGER DEFAULT X_MODE,
   timeout            IN  INTEGER DEFAULT MAXWAIT,
   release_on_commit  IN  BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE)
  RETURN INTEGER;
REQUEST.descriptionText: This function requests a lock with a specified mode. REQUEST is an overloaded function that accepts either a user-defined lock identifier, or the lock handle returned by the ALLOCATE_UNIQUE procedure.

SLEEP.name: dbms_lock.sleep
SLEEP.descriptionText: This procedure suspends the session for a specified period of time.

ADD_LOGFILE.name: dbms_logmnr.add_logfile
ADD_LOGFILE.descriptionText: This procedure adds a file to an existing or newly created list of log files for LogMiner to process.

COLUMN_PRESENT.name: dbms_logmnr.column_present
COLUMN_PRESENT.descriptionText: This function is designed to be used in conjunction with the MINE_VALUE function.

END_LOGMNR.name: dbms_logmnr.end_logmnr
END_LOGMNR.descriptionText: This procedure finishes a LogMiner session. Because this procedure performs cleanup operations that may not otherwise be done, you must use it to properly end a LogMiner session. This procedure is called automatically when you log out of a database session or when you call DBMS_LOGMNR.ADD_LOGFILE and specify the NEW option.

MINE_VALUE.name: dbms_logmnr.mine_value
MINE_VALUE.descriptionText: This function facilitates queries based on a colum\'s data value. This function takes two arguments. The first one specifies whether to mine the redo (REDO_VALUE) or undo (UNDO_VALUE) portion of the data. The second argument is a string that specifies the fully qualified name of the column to be mined. The MINE_VALUE function always returns a string that can be converted back to the original datatype.

REMOVE_LOGFILE.name: dbms_logmnr.remove_logfile
REMOVE_LOGFILE.descriptionText: This procedure removes a redo log file from an existing list of redo log files for LogMiner to process.

START_LOGMNR.name: dbms_logmnr.start_logmnr
START_LOGMNR.body:
startScn => 0
	, endScn => 0
	, startTime => '01-jan-1988'
	, endTime => '31-dec-2110'
	, DictFileName => ''
	, Options => 0
START_LOGMNR.bodyNoDefault:
startScn => $1
	, endScn => $2
	, startTime => $3
	, endTime => $4
	, DictFileName => $5
	, Options => $6
START_LOGMNR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGMNR.START_LOGMNR ( 
   startScn           IN NUMBER default 0,
   endScn             IN NUMBER default 0,
   startTime          IN DATE default '01-jan-1988',
   endTime            IN DATE default '31-dec-2110',
   DictFileName       IN VARCHAR2 default '',
   Options            IN BINARY_INTEGER default 0 );
START_LOGMNR.descriptionText: This procedure starts LogMiner by loading the dictionary that LogMiner will use to translate internal schema object identifiers to names.

BUILD.name: dbms_logmnr_d.build
BUILD.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGMNR_D.BUILD (
     dictionary_filename  IN  VARCHAR2,
     dictionary_location  IN  VARCHAR2,
     options              IN  NUMBER);
BUILD.descriptionText: This procedure extracts the LogMiner data dictionary to either the redo log files or to a flat file.

SET_TABLESPACE.name: dbms_logmnr_d.set_tablespace
SET_TABLESPACE.descriptionText: By default, all LogMiner tables are created to use the SYSAUX tablespace. However, it may be desirable to have LogMiner tables use an alternate tablespace. Use this procedure to move LogMiner tables to an alternate tablespace.

APPLY_SET.name: dbms_logstdby.apply_set
APPLY_SET.descriptionText: Use this procedure to set values of parameters that configure and manage SQL Apply in a logical standby database environment. All parameters, except for PRESERVE_COMMIT_ORDER, can be changed without having to stop SQL Apply.

APPLY_UNSET.name: dbms_logstdby.apply_unset
APPLY_UNSET.descriptionText: Use the APPLY_UNSET procedure to restore the default values of the parameters that you changed with the APPLY_SET procedure.

BUILD.name: dbms_logstdby.build
BUILD.descriptionText: Use this procedure on the primary database to record relevant metadata (LogMiner dictionary) information in the redo log, which will subsequently be used by SQL Apply. This procedure will enable database-wide primary- and unique-key supplemental logging, if necessary.

EDS_ADD_TABLE.name: dbms_logstdby.eds_add_table
EDS_ADD_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.EDS_ADD_TABLE (
     table_owner        IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name         IN VARCHAR2,
                             p_dblink           IN VARCHAR2);
EDS_ADD_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure adds EDS-based replication for the table. It should be invoked on the primary database first and then on the standby database.

EDS_EVOLVE_AUTOMATIC.name: dbms_logstdby.eds_evolve_automatic
EDS_EVOLVE_AUTOMATIC.descriptionText: This procedure either enables or disables automatic DDL handling for EDS tables.

EDS_EVOLVE_MANUAL.name: dbms_logstdby.eds_evolve_manual
EDS_EVOLVE_MANUAL.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.EDS_EVOLVE_MANUAL (
     options            IN VARCHAR2,
     table_owner        IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name         IN VARCHAR2);
EDS_EVOLVE_MANUAL.descriptionText: This procedure allows you to evolve EDS tables manually (that is, manually take compensating actions based on DDLs on the base tables with EDS-replication).

EDS_REMOVE_TABLE.name: dbms_logstdby.eds_remove_table
EDS_REMOVE_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.EDS_REMOVE_TABLE (
     table_owner        IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name         IN VARCHAR2,
EDS_REMOVE_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure removes EDS-based replication for the specified table. It also drops the shadow table and triggers.

INSTANTIATE_TABLE.name: dbms_logstdby.instantiate_table
INSTANTIATE_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.INSTANTIATE_TABLE (
     schema_name         IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name          IN VARCHAR2,
     dblink              IN VARCHAR2);
INSTANTIATE_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure creates and populates a table in the standby database from a corresponding table in the primary database. The table requires the name of the database link (dblink) as an input parameter. If the table already exists in the logical standby database, it will be dropped and re-created based on the table definition at the primary database. This procedure only brings over the data associated with the table, and not the associated indexes and constraints.

IS_APPLY_SERVER.name: dbms_logstdby.is_apply_server
IS_APPLY_SERVER.descriptionText: This function returns TRUE if it is executed from PL/SQL in the context of a logical standby apply server process. This function is used in conjunction with triggers that have the fire_once parameter in the DBMS_DDL.SET_TRIGGER_FIRING_PROPERTY subprogram set to FALSE (the default is TRUE). Such triggers are executed when the relevant target is updated by an apply process. This function can be used within the body of the trigger to ensure that the trigger takes different (or no) actions on the primary or on the standby.

MAP_PRIMARY_SCN.name: dbms_logstdby.map_primary_scn
MAP_PRIMARY_SCN.descriptionText: Returns an SCN on the standby that predates the supplied SCN from the primary database by at least 5 minutes. This function can be used to determine a safe SCN to use in a compensating flashback database operation at the logical standby database, following a flashback database operation or a point-in-time recovery operation at the primary database.

PREPARE_FOR_NEW_PRIMARY.name: dbms_logstdby.prepare_for_new_primary
PREPARE_FOR_NEW_PRIMARY.descriptionText: The PREPARE_FOR_NEW_PRIMARY procedure must be invoked at a logical standby database following a failover if that standby database was not the target of the failover operation. Such a standby database must process the exact same set of redo logs processed at the new primary database. This routine ensures that the local logical standby database has not processed more redo than the new primary database and reports the set of archive logs that must be replaced to ensure consistency. The set of replacement logs will be reported in the alert.log. These logs must be copied to the logical standby and registered using the ALTER DATABASE REGISTER LOGICAL LOGFILE statement.

PURGE_SESSION.name: dbms_logstdby.purge_session
PURGE_SESSION.descriptionText: Identifies all archived redo log files that have been applied to the logical standby database and are no longer needed by SQL Apply. Once identified, you can issue operating system commands to delete some or all of the unnecessary archived redo log files.

REBUILD.name: dbms_logstdby.rebuild
REBUILD.descriptionText: This procedure is used if a database that has recently changed its role to a primary database following a failover operation fails to record relevant metadata (including the LogMiner dictionary) in the redo stream required for other logical standby databases.

SET_TABLESPACE.name: dbms_logstdby.set_tablespace
SET_TABLESPACE.descriptionText: Moves metadata tables required by SQL Apply to the user-specified tablespace. By default, the metadata tables are created in the SYSAUX tablespace. SQL Apply cannot be running when you invoke this procedure.

SKIP.name: dbms_logstdby.skip
SKIP.body:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => NULL
	, object_name => NULL
	, proc_name => NULL
	, use_like => TRUE
	, esc => NULL
SKIP.bodyNoDefault:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => $2
	, object_name => $3
	, proc_name => $4
	, use_like => $5
	, esc => $6
SKIP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.SKIP (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     proc_name                 IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     use_like                  IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
     esc                       IN CHAR1 DEFAULT NULL);
SKIP.descriptionText: The SKIP procedure can be used to define rules that will be used by SQL Apply to skip the application of certain changes to the logical standby database. For example, the SKIP procedure can be used to skip changes to a subset of tables in the logical standby database. It can also be used to specify DDL statements that should not be applied at the logical standby database or should be modified before they are applied in the logical standby database. One reason why a DDL statement may need to be modified is to accommodate a different directory structure on the logical standby database.

SKIP_ERROR.name: dbms_logstdby.skip_error
SKIP_ERROR.body:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => NULL
	, object_name => NULL
	, proc_name => NULL
	, use_like => NULL
	, esc => NULL
SKIP_ERROR.bodyNoDefault:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => $2
	, object_name => $3
	, proc_name => $4
	, use_like => $5
	, esc => $6
SKIP_ERROR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.SKIP_ERROR (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     proc_name                 IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     use_like                  IN BOOLEAN  DEFAULT NULL,
     esc                       IN CHAR1    DEFAULT NULL);
SKIP_ERROR.descriptionText: Upon encountering an error, the logical standby database uses the criteria contained in this procedure to determine a course of action. The default action when a match is found is to skip the error and continue with applying changes. However, if a procedure is supplied, then SKIP_ERROR can take other actions depending on the situation. It can do nothing, which causes SQL Apply to stop, or it can change the error message text and stop SQL Apply, or it can actually skip the error.

SKIP_TRANSACTION.name: dbms_logstdby.skip_transaction
SKIP_TRANSACTION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.SKIP_TRANSACTION (
     xidusn          IN NUMBER,
     xidslt          IN NUMBER,
     xidsqn          IN NUMBER);
SKIP_TRANSACTION.descriptionText: This procedure provides a way to skip (ignore) applying transactions to the logical standby database. You can skip specific transactions by specifying transaction identification information.

UNSKIP.name: dbms_logstdby.unskip
UNSKIP.body:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => NULL
	, object_name => $2
	, container_name => NULL
UNSKIP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.UNSKIP (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFUALT NULL,
     container_name            IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
UNSKIP.descriptionText: Use the UNSKIP procedure to delete rules specified earlier with the SKIP procedure. The parameters specified in the UNSKIP procedure must match exactly for it to delete an already-specified rule.

UNSKIP_ERROR.name: dbms_logstdby.unskip_error
UNSKIP_ERROR.body:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => NULL
	, object_name => NULL
	, container_name => NULL
UNSKIP_ERROR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.UNSKIP_ERROR (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     container_name            IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
UNSKIP_ERROR.descriptionText: Use the UNSKIP_ERROR procedure to delete rules specified earlier with the SKIP_ERROR procedure. The parameters specified in the UNSKIP_ERROR procedure must match exactly for the procedure to delete an already-specified rule.

UNSKIP_TRANSACTION.name: dbms_logstdby.unskip_transaction
UNSKIP_TRANSACTION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.UNSKIP_TRANSACTION (
     xidusn_p         IN NUMBER,
     xidslt_p         IN NUMBER,
     xidsqn_p         IN NUMBER);
UNSKIP_TRANSACTION.descriptionText: Use the UNSKIP_TRANSACTION procedure to delete rules specified earlier with the SKIP_TRANSACTION procedure. The parameters specified in the UNSKIP_TRANSACTION procedure must match exactly for the procedure to delete an already-specified rule.

CLEAR_ALL_CONTEXT.name: dbms_logstdby_context.clear_all_context
CLEAR_ALL_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure clears all parameters contained within namespace LSBY_APPLY_CONTEXT.

CLEAR_CONTEXT.name: dbms_logstdby_context.clear_context
CLEAR_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure clears the specific parameter.

GET_CONTEXT.name: dbms_logstdby_context.get_context
GET_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the value for the specified parameter.

CLOSE.name: dbms_metadata.close
CLOSE.descriptionText: This procedure is used for both retrieval and submission. This procedure invalidates the handle returned by OPEN (or OPENW) and cleans up the associated state.

CONVERT.name: dbms_metadata.convert
CONVERT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_METADATA.CONVERT (
   handle   IN NUMBER,
   document IN sys.XMLType)
 RETURN sys.ku$_multi_ddls;

DBMS_METADATA.CONVERT (
  handle   IN NUMBER,
  document IN CLOB)
 RETURN sys.ku$_multi_ddls;
CONVERT.descriptionText: The CONVERT functions and procedures transform input XML documents. The CONVERT functions return creation DDL. The CONVERT procedures return either XML or DDL, depending on the specified transforms.

FETCH_XML.name: dbms_metadata.fetch_xml
FETCH_XML.descriptionText: These functions and procedures return metadata for objects meeting the criteria established by OPEN, SET_FILTER, SET_COUNT, ADD_TRANSFORM, and so on. See "Usage Notes" for the variants.

GET_QUERY.name: dbms_metadata.get_query
GET_QUERY.descriptionText: This function returns the text of the queries that are used by FETCH_xxx. This function assists in debugging.

OPEN.name: dbms_metadata.open
OPEN.bodyFullText:
DBMS_METADATA.OPEN (
   object_type  IN VARCHAR2,
   version      IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'COMPATIBLE',
   model        IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'ORACLE', 
   network_link IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL)
 RETURN NUMBER;
OPEN.descriptionText: This function specifies the type of object to be retrieved, the version of its metadata, and the object model. The return value is an opaque context handle for the set of objects to be used in subsequent calls.

OPENW.name: dbms_metadata.openw
OPENW.bodyFullText:
DBMS_METADATA.OPENW
  (object_type  IN VARCHAR2,
  version       IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'COMPATIBLE',
  model         IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'ORACLE') 
 RETURN NUMBER;
OPENW.descriptionText: This function specifies the type of object to be submitted and the object model. The return value is an opaque context handle.

PUT.name: dbms_metadata.put
PUT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_METADATA.PUT (
   handle     IN             NUMBER,
   document   IN             sys.XMLType,
   flags      IN             NUMBER,
   results    IN OUT NOCOPY  sys.ku$_SubmitResults)
  RETURN BOOLEAN;

DBMS_METADATA.PUT (
   handle     IN             NUMBER,
   document   IN             CLOB,
   flags      IN             NUMBER,
   results    IN OUT NOCOPY  sys.ku$_SubmitResults)
 RETURN BOOLEAN;
PUT.descriptionText: This function submits an XML document containing object metadata to the database to create the object.

SET_COUNT.name: dbms_metadata.set_count
SET_COUNT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_METADATA.SET_COUNT (
   handle           IN NUMBER,
   value            IN NUMBER,
   object_type_path IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
SET_COUNT.descriptionText: This procedure specifies the maximum number of objects to be retrieved in a single FETCH_xxx call. By default, each call to FETCH_xxx returns one object. You can use the SET_COUNT procedure to override this default. If FETCH_xxx is called from a client, specifying a count value greater than 1 can result in fewer server round trips and, therefore, improved performance.

SET_FILTER.name: dbms_metadata.set_filter
SET_FILTER.bodyFullText:

DBMS_METADATA.SET_FILTER (

   value             IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   object_type_path  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);

DBMS_METADATA.SET_FILTER (
   handle            IN NUMBER,
   name              IN VARCHAR2,
   value             IN NUMBER,
   object_type_path  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
SET_FILTER.descriptionText: This procedure specifies restrictions on the objects to be retrieved, for example, the object name or schema.

SET_TRANSFORM_PARAM.descriptionText: These procedures are used for both retrieval and submission. SET_TRANSFORM_PARAM and SET_REMAP_PARAM specify parameters to the XSLT stylesheet identified by transform_handle.Use them to modify or customize the output of the transform.

   scheme_name  IN VARCHAR2)
 RETURN CLOB;

GET_VALIDATOR.name: dbms_mgd_id_utl.get_validator
GET_VALIDATOR.descriptionText: This function returns the Oracle Database tag data translation schema.

REFRESH_CATEGORY.name: dbms_mgd_id_utl.refresh_category
REFRESH_CATEGORY.descriptionText: This function refreshes the metadata information on the Java stack for the specified category. This function must be called before using MGD_ID functions.

REMOVE_CATEGORY.name: dbms_mgd_id_utl.remove_category
REMOVE_CATEGORY.descriptionText: This procedure removes a category including all the related TDT XML. This procedure is overloaded. The different functionality of each form of syntax is presented along with the definitions.

REMOVE_PROXY.name: dbms_mgd_id_utl.remove_proxy
REMOVE_PROXY.descriptionText: This procedure unsets the host and port of the proxy server.

REMOVE_SCHEME.name: dbms_mgd_id_utl.remove_scheme
REMOVE_SCHEME.descriptionText: This procedure removes a tag data translation scheme from a category.

SET_JAVA_LOGGING_LEVEL.name: dbms_mgd_id_utl.set_java_logging_level
SET_JAVA_LOGGING_LEVEL.descriptionText: This procedure sets the Java trace logging level.

SET_PLSQL_LOGGING_LEVEL.name: dbms_mgd_id_utl.set_plsql_logging_level
SET_PLSQL_LOGGING_LEVEL.descriptionText: This procedure sets the PL/SQL trace logging level.

SET_PROXY.name: dbms_mgd_id_utl.set_proxy
SET_PROXY.descriptionText: This procedure sets the host and port of the proxy server for Internet access. This procedure must be called if the database server accesses the Internet using a proxy server. Internet access is necessary because some rules need to look up the Object Naming Service (ONS) table to get the company prefix index.

VALIDATE_SCHEME.name: dbms_mgd_id_utl.validate_scheme
VALIDATE_SCHEME.descriptionText: This function validates the input tag data translation XML against the Oracle Database tag data translation schema.

The MGW_GATEWAY view lists Messaging Gateway status and configuration information that pertains to the cleanup actions.

SHUTDOWN.name: dbms_mgwadm.shutdown
SHUTDOWN.descriptionText: This procedure shuts down the Messaging Gateway agent. No propagation activity occurs until Messaging Gateway is restarted.

CLIENT_ID_STAT_DISABLE.name: dbms_monitor.client_id_stat_disable
CLIENT_ID_STAT_DISABLE.descriptionText: This procedure will disable statistics accumulation for all instances and remove the accumulated results from V$CLIENT_STATS view enabled by the CLIENT_ID_STAT_ENABLE Procedure.

CLIENT_ID_STAT_ENABLE.name: dbms_monitor.client_id_stat_enable
CLIENT_ID_STAT_ENABLE.descriptionText: This procedure enables statistic gathering for a given Client Identifier. Statistics gathering is global for the database and persistent across instance starts and restarts. That is, statistics are enabled for all instances of the same database, including restarts. Statistics are viewable through V$CLIENT_STATS views.

CLIENT_ID_TRACE_DISABLE.name: dbms_monitor.client_id_trace_disable
CLIENT_ID_TRACE_DISABLE.descriptionText: This procedure will disable tracing enabled by the CLIENT_ID_TRACE_ENABLE Procedure.

CLIENT_ID_TRACE_ENABLE.name: dbms_monitor.client_id_trace_enable
CLIENT_ID_TRACE_ENABLE.body:
client_id => $1
	, waits => TRUE
	, binds => FALSE
	, plan_stat => NULL
CLIENT_ID_TRACE_ENABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MONITOR.CLIENT_ID_TRACE_ENABLE(
 client_id    IN  VARCHAR2,
 waits        IN  BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
 binds        IN  BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
 plan_stat    IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CLIENT_ID_TRACE_ENABLE.descriptionText: This procedure will enable the trace for a given client identifier globally for the database.

DATABASE_TRACE_DISABLE.name: dbms_monitor.database_trace_disable
DATABASE_TRACE_DISABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MONITOR.DATABASE_TRACE_DISABLE(
   instance_name  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
DATABASE_TRACE_DISABLE.descriptionText: This procedure disables SQL trace for the whole database or a specific instance.

DATABASE_TRACE_ENABLE.name: dbms_monitor.database_trace_enable
DATABASE_TRACE_ENABLE.body:
waits => TRUE
	, binds => FALSE
	, instance_name => NULL
	, plan_stat => NULL
DATABASE_TRACE_ENABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MONITOR.DATABASE_TRACE_ENABLE(
   waits          IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   binds          IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
   instance_name  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   plan_stat      IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
DATABASE_TRACE_ENABLE.descriptionText: This procedure enables SQL trace for the whole database or a specific instance.

SERV_MOD_ACT_STAT_DISABLE.name: dbms_monitor.serv_mod_act_stat_disable
SERV_MOD_ACT_STAT_DISABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MONITOR.SERV_MOD_ACT_STAT_DISABLE(
   service_name    IN VARCHAR2,
   module_name     IN VARCHAR2,
   action_name     IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT ALL_ACTIONS);
SERV_MOD_ACT_STAT_DISABLE.descriptionText: This procedure will disable statistics accumulation and remove the accumulated results from V$SERV_MOD_ACT_STATS view. Statistics disabling is persistent for the database. That is, service statistics are disabled for instances of the same database (plus dblinks that have been activated as a result of the enable).

SERV_MOD_ACT_STAT_ENABLE.name: dbms_monitor.serv_mod_act_stat_enable
SERV_MOD_ACT_STAT_ENABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MONITOR.SERV_MOD_ACT_STAT_ENABLE(
   service_name    IN VARCHAR2,
   module_name     IN VARCHAR2,
   action_name     IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT ALL_ACTIONS);
SERV_MOD_ACT_STAT_ENABLE.descriptionText: This procedure enables statistic gathering for a given combination of Service Name, MODULE and ACTION. Calling this procedure enables statistic gathering for a hierarchical combination of Service name, MODULE name, and ACTION name on all instances for the same database. Statistics are accessible by means of the V$SERV_MOD_ACT_STATS view.

SERV_MOD_ACT_TRACE_DISABLE.name: dbms_monitor.serv_mod_act_trace_disable
SERV_MOD_ACT_TRACE_DISABLE.body:
service_name => $1
	, module_name => $2
	, action_name => ALL_ACTIONS
	, instance_name => NULL
SERV_MOD_ACT_TRACE_DISABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MONITOR.SERV_MOD_ACT_TRACE_DISABLE(
   service_name    IN  VARCHAR2,
   module_name     IN  VARCHAR2,
   action_name     IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT ALL_ACTIONS,
   instance_name   IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
SERV_MOD_ACT_TRACE_DISABLE.descriptionText: This procedure will disable the trace at ALL enabled instances for a given combination of Service Name, MODULE, and ACTION name globally.

SERV_MOD_ACT_TRACE_ENABLE.name: dbms_monitor.serv_mod_act_trace_enable
SERV_MOD_ACT_TRACE_ENABLE.body:

	, waits => TRUE
	, binds => FALSE
	, instance_name => NULL
	, plan_stat => NULL
SERV_MOD_ACT_TRACE_ENABLE.bodyNoDefault:
service_name => $1
	, module_name => $2
	, action_name => $3
	, waits => $4
	, binds => $5
	, instance_name => $6
	, plan_stat => $7
SERV_MOD_ACT_TRACE_ENABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MONITOR.SERV_MOD_ACT_TRACE_ENABLE(
   service_name    IN VARCHAR2,

   binds           IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
   instance_name   IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL, 
   plan_stat       IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
SERV_MOD_ACT_TRACE_ENABLE.descriptionText: This procedure will enable SQL tracing for a given combination of Service Name, MODULE and ACTION globally unless an instance_name is specified.

SESSION_TRACE_DISABLE.name: dbms_monitor.session_trace_disable
SESSION_TRACE_DISABLE.descriptionText: This procedure will disable the trace for a given database session at the local instance.

session_id => NULL
	, serial_num => NULL

SESSION_TRACE_ENABLE.descriptionText: This procedure enables a SQL trace for the given Session ID on the local instance

BEGIN_TABLE_REORGANIZATION.name: dbms_mview.begin_table_reorganization
BEGIN_TABLE_REORGANIZATION.descriptionText: This procedure performs a process to preserve materialized view data needed for refresh. It must be called before a master table is reorganized.

END_TABLE_REORGANIZATION.name: dbms_mview.end_table_reorganization
END_TABLE_REORGANIZATION.descriptionText: This procedure ensures that the materialized view data for the master table is valid and that the master table is in the proper state. It must be called after a master table is reorganized.

ESTIMATE_MVIEW_SIZE.name: dbms_mview.estimate_mview_size
ESTIMATE_MVIEW_SIZE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MVIEW.ESTIMATE_MVIEW_SIZE (
   stmt_id       IN  VARCHAR2,
   select_clause IN  VARCHAR2,
   num_rows      OUT NUMBER,
   num_bytes     OUT NUMBER);
ESTIMATE_MVIEW_SIZE.descriptionText: This procedure estimates the size of a materialized view that you might create, in bytes and number of rows.

EXPLAIN_MVIEW.name: dbms_mview.explain_mview
EXPLAIN_MVIEW.descriptionText: This procedure enables you to learn what is possible with a materialized view or potential materialized view. For example, you can determine if a materialized view is fast refreshable and what types of query rewrite you can perform with a particular materialized view.

EXPLAIN_REWRITE.name: dbms_mview.explain_rewrite
EXPLAIN_REWRITE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MVIEW.EXPLAIN_REWRITE (
    query           VARCHAR2,
    mv              VARCHAR2(30),
    statement_id    VARCHAR2(30));
EXPLAIN_REWRITE.descriptionText: This procedure enables you to learn why a query failed to rewrite, or, if it rewrites, which materialized views will be used. Using the results from the procedure, you can take the appropriate action needed to make a query rewrite if at all possible. The query specified in the EXPLAIN_REWRITE statement is never actually executed.

I_AM_A_REFRESH.name: dbms_mview.i_am_a_refresh
I_AM_A_REFRESH.descriptionText: This function returns the value of the I_AM_REFRESH package state.

PMARKER.name: dbms_mview.pmarker
PMARKER.descriptionText: This function returns a partition marker from a rowid. It is used for Partition Change Tracking (PCT).

PURGE_DIRECT_LOAD_LOG.name: dbms_mview.purge_direct_load_log
PURGE_DIRECT_LOAD_LOG.descriptionText: This procedure removes entries from the direct loader log after they are no longer needed for any known materialized view. This procedure usually is used in environments using Oracl\'s data warehousing technology.

PURGE_LOG.name: dbms_mview.purge_log
PURGE_LOG.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MVIEW.PURGE_LOG (
   master        IN   VARCHAR2,
   num           IN   BINARY_INTEGER := 1,
   flag          IN   VARCHAR2       := 'NOP');
PURGE_LOG.descriptionText: This procedure purges rows from the materialized view log.

PURGE_MVIEW_FROM_LOG.name: dbms_mview.purge_mview_from_log
PURGE_MVIEW_FROM_LOG.descriptionText: This procedure is called on the master site or master materialized view site to delete the rows in materialized view refresh related data dictionary tables maintained at the master for the specified materialized view identified by mview_id or the combination of mviewowner, mviewname, and mviewsite. If the materialized view specified is the oldest materialized view to have refreshed from any of the master tables or master materialized views, then the materialized view log is also purged. This procedure does not unregister the materialized view.

CONTAINS_HOST.name: dbms_network_acl_utility.contains_host
CONTAINS_HOST.bodyFullText:
DBMS_NETWORK_ACL_UTILITY.CONTAINS_HOST (
   host      IN    VARCHAR2,
   domain    IN    VARCHAR2)
 RETURN NUMBER;
CONTAINS_HOST.descriptionText: This function determines if the given host is equal to or contained in the given host, domain, or subnet. It handles different representation of the same IP address or subnet. For example, an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address is considered equal to the IPv4-native address it represents. It does not perform domain name resolution when evaluating the host or domain.

DOMAIN_LEVEL.name: dbms_network_acl_utility.domain_level
DOMAIN_LEVEL.descriptionText: This function returns the domain level of the given host name, domain, or subnet.

DOMAINS.name: dbms_network_acl_utility.domains
DOMAINS.descriptionText: For a given host, this function returns the domains whose ACL assigned determines if a user has the privilege to access the given host or not. When the IP address of the host is given, return the subnets instead.

EQUALS_HOST.name: dbms_network_acl_utility.equals_host
EQUALS_HOST.bodyFullText:
DBMS_NETWORK_ACL_UTILITY.EQUALS_HOST (
   host1    IN    VARCHAR2,
   host2    IN    VARCHAR2)
 RETURN NUMBER;
EQUALS_HOST.descriptionText: This function determines if the two given hosts, domains, or subnets are equal. It handles different representation of the same IP address or subnet. For example, an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address is considered equal to the IPv4- native address it represents. It does not perform domain name resolution when comparing the two hosts or domains.

ESTIMATE_CPU_UNITS.name: dbms_odci.estimate_cpu_units
ESTIMATE_CPU_UNITS.descriptionText: This function returns the approximate number of CPU instructions (in thousands) corresponding to a specified time interval (in seconds). This information can be used to associate the CPU cost with a user-defined function for the extensible optimizer.

BEGIN_INSTANTIATION.name: dbms_offline_og.begin_instantiation
BEGIN_INSTANTIATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_OFFLINE_OG.BEGIN_INSTANTIATION (
   gname     IN   VARCHAR2,
   new_site  IN   VARCHAR2
   fname     IN   VARCHAR2);
BEGIN_INSTANTIATION.descriptionText: This procedure starts offline instantiation of a master group. You must call this procedure from the master definition site.

BEGIN_LOAD.name: dbms_offline_og.begin_load
BEGIN_LOAD.descriptionText: This procedure disables triggers while data is imported to the new master site as part of offline instantiation. You must call this procedure from the new master site.

END_INSTANTIATION.name: dbms_offline_og.end_instantiation
END_INSTANTIATION.descriptionText: This procedure completes offline instantiation of a master group. You must call this procedure from the master definition site.

END_LOAD.name: dbms_offline_og.end_load
END_LOAD.bodyFullText:
DBMS_OFFLINE_OG.END_LOAD (
   gname     IN   VARCHAR2,
   new_site  IN   VARCHAR2
   fname     IN   VARCHAR2);
END_LOAD.descriptionText: This procedure reenables triggers after importing data to new master site as part of offline instantiation. You must call this procedure from the new master site.

RESUME_SUBSET_OF_MASTERS.name: dbms_offline_og.resume_subset_of_masters
RESUME_SUBSET_OF_MASTERS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_OFFLINE_OG.RESUME_SUBSET_OF_MASTERS (
   gname     IN  VARCHAR2,
   new_site  IN  VARCHAR2
   override  IN  BOOLEAN := FALSE);
RESUME_SUBSET_OF_MASTERS.descriptionText: When you add a new master site to a master group by performing an offline instantiation of a master site, it might take some time to complete the offline instantiation process. This procedure resumes replication activity at all existing sites, except the new site, during offline instantiation of a master group. You typically execute this procedure after executing the DBMS_OFFLINE_OG.BEGIN_INSTANTIATION procedure. You must call this procedure from the master definition site.

CLEAR_USED.name: dbms_outln.clear_used
CLEAR_USED.descriptionText: This procedure clears the outline\'use\' flag.

CREATE_OUTLINE.name: dbms_outln.create_outline
CREATE_OUTLINE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_OUTLN.CREATE_OUTLINE (
   hash_value    IN NUMBER,
   child_number  IN NUMBER,
   category      IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'DEFAULT');
CREATE_OUTLINE.descriptionText: This procedure generates an outline by reparsing the SQL statement from the shared cursor identified by hash value and child number.

DROP_BY_CAT.name: dbms_outln.drop_by_cat
DROP_BY_CAT.descriptionText: This procedure drops outlines that belong to a particular category. While outlines are put into the DEFAULT category unless otherwise specified, users have the option of grouping their outlines into groups called categories.

DROP_UNUSED.name: dbms_outln.drop_unused
DROP_UNUSED.descriptionText: This procedure drops outlines that have never been applied in the compilation of a SQL statement.

EXACT_TEXT_SIGNATURES.name: dbms_outln.exact_text_signatures
EXACT_TEXT_SIGNATURES.descriptionText: This procedure updates outline signatures to those that compute based on exact text matching.

UPDATE_BY_CAT.name: dbms_outln.update_by_cat
UPDATE_BY_CAT.descriptionText: This procedure changes the category of all outlines in one category to a new category.

UPDATE_SIGNATURES.name: dbms_outln.update_signatures
UPDATE_SIGNATURES.descriptionText: This procedure updates outline signatures to the current versio\'s signature.

DISABLE.name: dbms_output.disable
DISABLE.descriptionText: This procedure disables calls to PUT, PUT_LINE, NEW_LINE, GET_LINE, and GET_LINES, and purges the buffer of any remaining information.

ENABLE.name: dbms_output.enable
ENABLE.descriptionText: This procedure enables calls to PUT, PUT_LINE, NEW_LINE, GET_LINE, and GET_LINES. Calls to these procedures are ignored if the DBMS_OUTPUT package is not activated.

GET_LINE.name: dbms_output.get_line
GET_LINE.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves a single line of buffered information.

GET_LINES.name: dbms_output.get_lines
GET_LINES.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves an array of lines from the buffer.

NEW_LINE.name: dbms_output.new_line
NEW_LINE.descriptionText: This procedure puts an end-of-line marker. The GET_LINE Procedure and the GET_LINES Procedure return "lines" as delimited by "newlines". Every call to the PUT_LINE Procedure or NEW_LINE Procedure generates a line that is returned by GET_LINE(S).

PUT.name: dbms_output.put
PUT.descriptionText: This procedure places a partial line in the buffer.

PUT_LINE.name: dbms_output.put_line
PUT_LINE.descriptionText: This procedure places a line in the buffer.

ADM_DROP_CHUNKS.name: dbms_parallel_execute.adm_drop_chunks
ADM_DROP_CHUNKS.descriptionText: This procedure drops all chunks of the specified task owned by the specified owner.

ADM_DROP_TASK.name: dbms_parallel_execute.adm_drop_task
ADM_DROP_TASK.descriptionText: This procedure drops the task of the specified user and all related chunks.

ADM_STOP_TASK.name: dbms_parallel_execute.adm_stop_task
ADM_STOP_TASK.descriptionText: This procedure stops the task of the specified owner and related job slaves.

ADM_TASK_STATUS.name: dbms_parallel_execute.adm_task_status
ADM_TASK_STATUS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.ADM_TASK_STATUS  (
   task_owner      IN  VARCHAR2,
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2)
 RETURN NUMBER;
ADM_TASK_STATUS.descriptionText: This function returns the task status.

CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_NUMBER_COL.name: dbms_parallel_execute.create_chunks_by_number_col
CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_NUMBER_COL.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_NUMBER_COL (
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_owner     IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_name      IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_column    IN  VARCHAR2,
   chunk_size      IN  NUMBER);
CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_NUMBER_COL.descriptionText: This procedure chunks the table (associated with the specified task) by the specified column. The specified column must be a NUMBER column. This procedure takes the MIN and MAX value of the column, and then divides the range evenly according to chunk_size. The chunks are:

CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_ROWID.name: dbms_parallel_execute.create_chunks_by_rowid
CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_ROWID.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_ROWID (
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_owner     IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_name      IN  VARCHAR2,
   by_row          IN  BOOLEAN,
   chunk_size      IN  NUMBER);
CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_ROWID.descriptionText: This procedure chunks the table (associated with the specified task) by ROWID. num_row and num_block are approximate guidance for the size of each chunk. The table to be chunked must be a physical table with physical ROWID having views and table functions. Index-organized tables are not allowed.

CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_SQL.name: dbms_parallel_execute.create_chunks_by_sql
CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_SQL.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_SQL (
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   sql_statement   IN  CLOB,
   by_rowid        IN  BOOLEAN);
CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_SQL.descriptionText: This procedure chunks the table (associated with the specified task) by means of a user-provided SELECT statement. The SELECT statement that returns the range of each chunk must have two columns: start_id and end_id. If the task is to chunk by ROWID, then the two columns must be of ROWID type. If the task is to chunk the table by NUMBER column, then the two columns must be of NUMBER type. The procedure provides the flexibility to users who want to deploy user-defined chunk algorithms.

CREATE_TASK.name: dbms_parallel_execute.create_task
CREATE_TASK.descriptionText: This procedure creates a task for the current user. The pairing of task_name and current_user must be unique.

DROP_CHUNKS.name: dbms_parallel_execute.drop_chunks
DROP_CHUNKS.descriptionText: This procedure drops the tas\'s chunks.

DROP_TASK.name: dbms_parallel_execute.drop_task
DROP_TASK.descriptionText: This procedure drops the task and all related chunks.

GENERATE_TASK_NAME.name: dbms_parallel_execute.generate_task_name
GENERATE_TASK_NAME.descriptionText: This function returns a unique name for a task. The name is of the form prefixN where N is a number from a sequence. If no prefix is specified, the generated name is, by default, TASK$_1, TASK$_2, TASK$_3, and so on. If\'SCOT\' is specified as the prefix, the name is SCOTT1, SCOTT2, and so on.

GET_NUMBER_COL_CHUNK.name: dbms_parallel_execute.get_number_col_chunk
GET_NUMBER_COL_CHUNK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.GET_NUMBER_COL_CHUNK (
   task_name       IN VARCHAR2,
   chunk_id        OUT NUMBER,
   start_rowid     OUT ROWID,      
   end_id          OUT ROWID,
   any_rows        OUT BOOLEAN);
GET_NUMBER_COL_CHUNK.descriptionText: This procedure picks an unassigned NUMBER chunk and changes it to ASSIGNED. If there are no more chunks to assign, any_rows is set to FALSE. Otherwise, the chunk_id, start, and end_id of the chunk are returned as OUT parameters. The chunk info in DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE_CHUNKS$ is updated as follows: STATUS becomes ASSIGNED; START_TIMESTAMP records the current time; END_TIMESTAMP is cleared.

GET_ROWID_CHUNK.name: dbms_parallel_execute.get_rowid_chunk
GET_ROWID_CHUNK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.GET_ROWID_CHUNK (
   task_name       IN VARCHAR2,
   chunk_id        OUT NUMBER,
   start_rowid     OUT ROWID,      
   end_id          OUT ROWID,
   any_rows        OUT BOOLEAN);
GET_ROWID_CHUNK.descriptionText: This procedure picks an unassigned ROWID chunk and changes it to ASSIGNED. If there are no more chunks to assign, any_rows is set to FALSE. Otherwise, the chunk_id, start, and end_id of the chunk are returned as OUT parameters. The chunk info in DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE_CHUNKS$ is updated as follows: STATUS becomes ASSIGNED; START_TIMESTAMP records the current time; END_TIMESTAMP is cleared.

PURGE_PROCESSED_CHUNKS.name: dbms_parallel_execute.purge_processed_chunks
PURGE_PROCESSED_CHUNKS.descriptionText: This procedure deletes all the processed chunks whose status is PROCESSED or PROCESSED_WITH_ERROR.

RESUME_TASK.name: dbms_parallel_execute.resume_task
RESUME_TASK.body:
task_name => $1
	, sql_stmt => $2
	, language_flag => $3
	, edition => NULL
	, apply_crossedition_trigger => NULL
	, fire_apply_trigger => TRUE
	, parallel_level => 0
	, job_class => 'DEFAULT_JOB_CLASS'
	, force => FALSE
RESUME_TASK.bodyNoDefault:
task_name => $1
	, sql_stmt => $2
	, language_flag => $3
	, edition => $4
	, apply_crossedition_trigger => $5
	, fire_apply_trigger => $6
	, parallel_level => $7
	, job_class => $8
	, force => $9
RESUME_TASK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.RESUME_TASK (
   task_name                     IN  VARCHAR2,
   sql_stmt                      IN  CLOB,   
   language_flag                 IN  NUMBER,
   edition                       IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   apply_crossedition_trigger    IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   fire_apply_trigger            IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT TRUE,
   parallel_level                IN  NUMBER    DEFAULT 0,
   job_class                     IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT 'DEFAULT_JOB_CLASS',
   force                         IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE);

DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.RESUME_TASK (
   task_name                     IN  VARCHAR2,
   force                         IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE);
RESUME_TASK.descriptionText: This procedure retries the specified the task if the RUN_TASK Procedure finished with an error, or resumes the task if a crash occurred. You can only invoke this procedure if the task is in a CRASHED or FINISHED_WITH_ERROR state. For a crashed serial execution, the state remains in processing. The FORCE option allows you to resume any task in PROCESSING state. However, it is your responsibility to determine that a crash has occurred. The procedure resumes processing the chunks which have not been processed. Also, chunks which are in PROCESSED_WITH_ERROR or ASSIGNED (due to crash) state are processed because those chunks did not commit. This procedure takes the same argument as the RUN_TASK Procedure. The overload which takes task_name as the only input argument re-uses the arguments provided in the previous invoking of the RUN_TASK Procedure or RESUME_TASK Procedures.

RUN_TASK.name: dbms_parallel_execute.run_task
RUN_TASK.body:
task_name => $1
	, sql_stmt => $2
	, language_flag => $3
	, edition => NULL

	, job_class => 'DEFAULT_JOB_CLASS'
RUN_TASK.bodyNoDefault:

	, sql_stmt => $2

	, apply_crossedition_trigger => $5
	, fire_apply_trigger => $6
	, parallel_level => $7
	, job_class => $8
RUN_TASK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.RUN_TASK (
   task_name                     IN  VARCHAR2,
   sql_stmt                      IN  CLOB,
   language_flag                 IN  NUMBER,
   edition                       IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   apply_crossedition_trigger    IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   fire_apply_trigger            IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT TRUE,
   parallel_level                IN  NUMBER    DEFAULT 0,
   job_class                     IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT 'DEFAULT_JOB_CLASS');
RUN_TASK.descriptionText: This procedure executes the specified statement (sql_stmt) on the chunks in parallel. It commits after processing each chunk. The specified statement must have two placeholders called start_id and end_id, respectively, which represent the range of the chunk to be processed. The type of each placeholder must be ROWID where ROWID-based chunking was used, or NUMBER where NUMBER-based chunking was used.

STOP_TASK.name: dbms_parallel_execute.stop_task

CLEANUP_GIDX.name: dbms_part.cleanup_gidx
CLEANUP_GIDX.descriptionText: As a consequence of prior partition maintenance operations with asynchronous global index maintenance, global indexes can contain entries pointing to data segments that no longer exist. These stale index rows will not cause any correctness issues or corruptions during any operation on the table or index, whether these are queries, DMLs, DDLs or analyze. This procedure will identify and cleanup these global indexes to ensure efficiency in terms of storage and performance.

CLEANUP_ONLINE_OP.name: dbms_part.cleanup_online_op
CLEANUP_ONLINE_OP.body:
schema_name => NULL
	, table_name => NULL
	, partition_name => NULL
CLEANUP_ONLINE_OP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PART.CLEANUP_ONLINE_OP (
   schema_name       IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   table_name        IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL, 
   partition_name    IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CLEANUP_ONLINE_OP.descriptionText: There are many possible points of failure when performing ALTER TABLE ... MOVE PARTITION ... ONLINE operations. This procedure pro-actively cleans up such failed online move operations instead of waiting for the background process (SMON) to do so.

BUILD_PART_INDEX.name: dbms_pclxutil.build_part_index

   pdb_name          IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL) 
 RETURN BOOLEAN;
CHECK_PLUG_COMPATIBILITY.descriptionText: This function uses an XML file describing a pluggable database (PDB) to determine whether it may be plugged into a given multitenant container database (CDB).

DESCRIBE.name: dbms_pdb.describe
DESCRIBE.descriptionText: This procedure generates an XML file describing the specified pluggable database (PDB). This file can then be passed to the CHECK_PLUG_COMPATIBILITY Function to determine if the PDB described by the XML file may be plugged into a given multitenant container database (CDB).

RECOVER.name: dbms_pdb.recover
RECOVER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PDB.RECOVER (
   pdb_descr_file    IN   VARCHAR2, 
   pdb_name          IN   VARCHAR2,
   filenames         IN   VARCHAR2);
RECOVER.descriptionText: This procedure generates an XML file describing a pluggable database by using data files belonging to the pluggable database. This XML file can then be used to plug the pluggable database into a multitenant container database (CDB) using CREATE PLUGGABLE DATABASE statement.This procedure is intended for cases when an XML file describing a pluggable database is corrupted or lost.

PROFILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.PROFILE (
     data_table_name           IN VARCHAR2,
     target_column_name        IN VARCHAR2,
     result_table_name         IN VARCHAR2,
     data_schema_name          IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
PROFILE.descriptionText: The PROFILE procedure generates rules that describe the cases (records) from the input data. For example, if a target column CHURN has values\'Ye\' and\'N\', PROFILE generates a set of rules describing the expected outcomes. Each profile includes a rule, record count, and a score distribution.

GET_POST_PROCESSED_SOURCE.name: dbms_preprocessor.get_post_processed_source
GET_POST_PROCESSED_SOURCE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PREPROCESSOR.GET_POST_PROCESSED_SOURCE (
   object_type    IN VARCHAR2,
   schema_name    IN VARCHAR2,
   object_name    IN VARCHAR2)
  RETURN source_lines_t;
GET_POST_PROCESSED_SOURCE.descriptionText: This overloaded function returns the post-processed source text. The different functionality of each form of syntax is presented along with the definition.

PRINT_POST_PROCESSED_SOURCE.name: dbms_preprocessor.print_post_processed_source
PRINT_POST_PROCESSED_SOURCE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PREPROCESSOR.PRINT_POST_PROCESSED_SOURCE (
   object_type    IN VARCHAR2,
   schema_name    IN VARCHAR2,
   object_name    IN VARCHAR2);
PRINT_POST_PROCESSED_SOURCE.descriptionText: This overloaded procedure calls DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE to let you view post-processed source text. The different functionality of each form of syntax is presented along with the definition.

CREATE_CAPTURE.name: dbms_privilege_capture.create_capture
CREATE_CAPTURE.body:
name => $1
	, description => NULL
	, type => G_DATABASE
	, roles => ROLE_NAME_LIST()
	, condition => NULL
CREATE_CAPTURE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PRIVILEGE_CAPTURE.CREATE_CAPTURE (
   name            IN  VARCHAR2,
   description     IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL, 
   type            IN  NUMBER DEFAULT G_DATABASE,
   roles           IN  ROLE_NAME_LIST DEFAULT ROLE_NAME_LIST(),
   condition       IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_CAPTURE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a privilege analysis policy that specifies the conditions for analyzing privilege use. It also optionally specifies the roles for which privilege use is to be analyzed, and the conditions under which privilege use is to be analyzed.

DISABLE_CAPTURE.name: dbms_privilege_capture.disable_capture
DISABLE_CAPTURE.descriptionText: This procedure stops the recording of privilege use for a specified privilege analysis policy. When a policy is disabled, privilege use meeting the policy condition is no longer recorded.

DROP_CAPTURE.name: dbms_privilege_capture.drop_capture
DROP_CAPTURE.descriptionText: This procedure removes a privilege analysis policy together with the data recorded. When a policy is removed, all previously recorded privilege use data associated with the policy is deleted.

ENABLE_CAPTURE.name: dbms_privilege_capture.enable_capture
ENABLE_CAPTURE.descriptionText: This procedure starts the recording of privilege analysis for a specified privilege analysis policy. After a policy is enabled, all privilege use under the policy condition is recorded.

GENERATE_RESULT.name: dbms_privilege_capture.generate_result
GENERATE_RESULT.descriptionText: This procedure populates the privilege analysis data dictionary views with data.

FLUSH_DATA.name: dbms_profiler.flush_data
FLUSH_DATA.descriptionText: This function flushes profiler data collected in the use\'s session. The data is flushed to database tables, which are expected to preexist.

GET_VERSION.name: dbms_profiler.get_version
GET_VERSION.descriptionText: This procedure gets the version of this API.

INTERNAL_VERSION_CHECK.name: dbms_profiler.internal_version_check
INTERNAL_VERSION_CHECK.descriptionText: This function verifies that this version of the DBMS_PROFILER package can work with the implementation in the database.

PAUSE_PROFILER.name: dbms_profiler.pause_profiler
PAUSE_PROFILER.descriptionText: This function pauses profiler data collection.

RESUME_PROFILER.name: dbms_profiler.resume_profiler
RESUME_PROFILER.descriptionText: This function resumes profiler data collection.

START_PROFILER.name: dbms_profiler.start_profiler
START_PROFILER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PROFILER.START_PROFILER(
   run_comment   IN VARCHAR2 := sysdate,
   run_comment1  IN VARCHAR2 :='',
   run_number    OUT BINARY_INTEGER)
 RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;

DBMS_PROFILER.START_PROFILER(
   run_comment IN VARCHAR2 := sysdate,
   run_comment1 IN VARCHAR2 :='')
RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;

DBMS_PROFILER.START_PROFILER(
   run_comment   IN VARCHAR2 := sysdate,
   run_comment1  IN VARCHAR2 :='',
   run_number    OUT BINARY_INTEGER);

DBMS_PROFILER.START_PROFILER(
   run_comment IN VARCHAR2 := sysdate,
   run_comment1 IN VARCHAR2 :='');
START_PROFILER.descriptionText: This function starts profiler data collection in the use\'s session.

STOP_PROFILER.name: dbms_profiler.stop_profiler
STOP_PROFILER.descriptionText: This function stops profiler data collection in the use\'s session.

RUN_INTERNAL_WORKER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PROFILER.RUN_INTERNAL_WORKER(
                TASK_NAME IN VARCHAR2 
        JOB_NAME IN VARCHAR2 
)

ALTER_PROPAGATION.name: dbms_propagation_adm.alter_propagation

propagation_name => $1
	, rule_set_name => NULL
	, remove_rule_set => FALSE
	, negative_rule_set_name => NULL
	, remove_negative_rule_set => FALSE
ALTER_PROPAGATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PROPAGATION_ADM.ALTER_PROPAGATION(
     propagation_name          IN  VARCHAR2,
     rule_set_name             IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
     remove_rule_set           IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE,
     negative_rule_set_name    IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
     remove_negative_rule_set  IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE);
ALTER_PROPAGATION.descriptionText: This procedure adds, alters, or removes a rule set for a propagation.

CREATE_PROPAGATION.name: dbms_propagation_adm.create_propagation
CREATE_PROPAGATION.body:
propagation_name => $1
	, source_queue => $2
	, destination_queue => $3
	, destination_dblink => NULL
	, rule_set_name => NULL
	, negative_rule_set_name => NULL
	, queue_to_queue => NULL
	, original_propagation_name => NULL
	, auto_merge_threshold => NULL
CREATE_PROPAGATION.bodyNoDefault:
propagation_name => $1
	, source_queue => $2
	, destination_queue => $3
	, destination_dblink => $4
	, rule_set_name => $5
	, negative_rule_set_name => $6
	, queue_to_queue => $7
	, original_propagation_name => $8
	, auto_merge_threshold => $9
CREATE_PROPAGATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_PROPAGATION_ADM.CREATE_PROPAGATION(
     propagation_name           IN  VARCHAR2,
     source_queue               IN  VARCHAR2,
     destination_queue          IN  VARCHAR2,
     destination_dblink         IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
     rule_set_name              IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
     negative_rule_set_name     IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
     queue_to_queue             IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT NULL,
     original_propagation_name  IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
     auto_merge_threshold       IN  NUMBER    DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_PROPAGATION.descriptionText: This procedure creates a propagation and specifies the source queue, destination queue, and any rule set for the propagation. A propagation propagates messages in a local source queue to a destination queue. The destination queue might or might not be in the same database as the source queue.

DROP_PROPAGATION.name: dbms_propagation_adm.drop_propagation
DROP_PROPAGATION.descriptionText: This procedure drops a propagation and deletes all messages for the destination queue in the source queue. This procedure also removes the schedule for propagation from the source queue to the destination queue.

STOP_PROPAGATION.name: dbms_propagation_adm.stop_propagation

GET_OPATCH_BUGS.name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_bugs
GET_OPATCH_BUGS.descriptionText: This function provides a bugs list in a patch if the patch number is given. If a patch number is not given, it lists all the bugs in the specified XML format.

GET_OPATCH_COUNT.name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_count
GET_OPATCH_COUNT.descriptionText: This function provides the total number of installed patches in XML format.

GET_OPATCH_DATA.name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_data
GET_OPATCH_DATA.descriptionText: This function provides top level patch information for the patch (such as Patch ID, patch creation time) in the XML element.

GET_OPATCH_FILES.name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_files
GET_OPATCH_FILES.descriptionText: This function provides the list of files modified in the given patch number in XML format.

GET_OPATCH_INSTALL_INFO.name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_install_info
GET_OPATCH_INSTALL_INFO.descriptionText: This function returns the XML element containing the ORACLE_HOME details such as patch and inventory location.

GET_OPATCH_LIST.name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_list
GET_OPATCH_LIST.descriptionText: This function provides list of patches installed as an XML element from the XML inventory.

GET_OPATCH_LSINVENTORY.name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_lsinventory
GET_OPATCH_LSINVENTORY.descriptionText: This function returns whole opatch inventory as XML instance document.

GET_OPATCH_OLAYS.name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_olays
GET_OPATCH_OLAYS.descriptionText: This function provides overlay patches for a given patch as XML element.

GET_OPATCH_PREQS.name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_preqs
GET_OPATCH_PREQS.descriptionText: This function provides prerequisite patches for a given patch as XML element.

GET_OPATCH_XSLT.name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_xslt
GET_OPATCH_XSLT.descriptionText: This function returns the style-sheet for the opatch XML inventory presentation. You can use the return type of this subprogram to perform XMLTRANSFORM and the transformed result has the same appearance as opatch text output.

GET_PENDING_ACTIVITY.name: dbms_qopatch.get_pending_activity
GET_PENDING_ACTIVITY.descriptionText: This function returns the information related to SQL patches applied on a single instance by querying the binary inventory. If this is Oracle Real Application Clusters (RAC) system, it will list the node names where the SQL patch is not applied.

GET_SQLPATCH_STATUS.name: dbms_qopatch.get_sqlpatch_status
GET_SQLPATCH_STATUS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_QOPATCH.GET_SQLPATCH_STATUS (
   patchnum IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
GET_SQLPATCH_STATUS.descriptionText: This procedure displays the SQL patch status by querying from SQL patch registry to produce complete patch level information. If the patch number is given, it displays the information specific to the given SQL patch, otherwise information for all SQL patches.

IS_PATCH_INSTALLED.name: dbms_qopatch.is_patch_installed
IS_PATCH_INSTALLED.descriptionText: This function provides information (such as patchID, application date, and SQL patch information) on the installed patch as XML node by querying the XML inventory.

PATCH_CONFLICT_DETECTION.name: dbms_qopatch.patch_conflict_detection
PATCH_CONFLICT_DETECTION.descriptionText: This function returns the conflicting patch for a given file, if it conflicts with an existing patch.

SET_CURRENT_OPINST.name: dbms_qopatch.set_current_opinst
SET_CURRENT_OPINST.descriptionText: This procedure sets the node name and instance to get the inventory details specific to it in an Oracle Real Application Clusters (RAC) environment.

NORMAL.name: dbms_random.normal
NORMAL.descriptionText: This function returns random numbers in a standard normal distribution.

RANDOM.name: dbms_random.random
RANDOM.descriptionText: This procedure generates a random number.

SEED.name: dbms_random.seed

STRING.name: dbms_random.string
STRING.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RANDOM.STRING
   opt  IN  CHAR,
   len  IN  NUMBER)
  RETURN VARCHAR2;
STRING.descriptionText: This function gets a random string.

TERMINATE.name: dbms_random.terminate
TERMINATE.descriptionText: When you are finished with the package, call the TERMINATE procedure.

VALUE.name: dbms_random.value
VALUE.descriptionText: The basic function gets a random number, greater than or equal to 0 and less than 1, with 38 digits to the right of the decimal (38-digit precision). Alternatively, you can get a random Oracle number x, where x is greater than or equal to low and less than high.

ABORT_REDEF_TABLE.name: dbms_redefinition.abort_redef_table
ABORT_REDEF_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_REDEFINITION.ABORT_REDEF_TABLE (
   uname                   IN  VARCHAR2,
   orig_table              IN  VARCHAR2,
   int_table               IN  VARCHAR2,
   part_name               IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL);
ABORT_REDEF_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure cleans up errors that occur during the redefinition process. This procedure can also be used to terminate the redefinition process any time after the START_REDEF_TABLE Procedure has been called and before the FINISH_REDEF_TABLE Procedure is called. This process will remove the temporary objects that are created by the redefinition process such as materialized view logs.

CAN_REDEF_TABLE.name: dbms_redefinition.can_redef_table
CAN_REDEF_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_REDEFINITION.CAN_REDEF_TABLE (
   uname         IN  VARCHAR2,
   tname        IN  VARCHAR2,
   options_flag  IN  PLS_INTEGER := 1,
   part_name     IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL);
CAN_REDEF_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure determines if a given table can be redefined online. This is the first step of the online redefinition process. If the table is not a candidate for online redefinition, an error message is raised.

	, dml_lock_timeout => $5
	, continue_after_errors => $6
FINISH_REDEF_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_REDEFINITION.FINISH_REDEF_TABLE (
   uname                   IN   VARCHAR2,
   orig_table              IN   VARCHAR2,
   int_table               IN   VARCHAR2,
   part_name               IN   VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   dml_lock_timeout        IN   PLS_INTEGER := NULL,
   continue_after_errors   IN   BOOLEAN := FALSE);
FINISH_REDEF_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure completes the redefinition process. Before this step, you can create new indexes, triggers, grants, and constraints on the interim table. The referential constraints involving the interim table must be disabled. After completing this step, the original table is redefined with the attributes and data of the interim table. The original table is locked briefly during this procedure.

   uname                       IN  VARCHAR2,
   tname                       IN  VARCHAR2,

   lob_compression_type        IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL,

   lob_store_as                IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL);
REDEF_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure provides a single interface that integrates several redefinition steps including the CAN_REDEF_TABLE Procedure, the START_REDEF_TABLE Procedure, the COPY_TABLE_DEPENDENTS Procedure and the FINISH_REDEF_TABLE Procedure. This procedure can change data storage properties including tablespaces (for table, partition, subpartition, index, LOB column), compress type (for table, partition, subpartition, index, LOB column) and STORE_AS clause for the LOB column.
